verses.sanskrit: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच । धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः । मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥ १ ॥
verses.translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after gathering on the holy field of Kurukshetra, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do, being desirous to fight?
verses.transliteration: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva kim akurvata sañjaya
verses.meaning: Dhritarashtra inquired about the events that transpired on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, where the armies of his sons and the Pandavas had assembled with the intent to fight.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच । दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा । आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ॥ २ ॥
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Then, seeing the army of the Pandavas arrayed in battle formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher and spoke the following words.
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanas tadā ācāryam upasaṅgamya rājā vacanam abravīt
verses.meaning: Sanjaya narrates how Duryodhana, upon observing the strategic arrangement of the Pandava army, sought counsel from his teacher, Drona.

verses.sanskrit: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणाम् आचार्य महतीं चमूम् । व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥ ३ ॥
verses.translation: Behold, O teacher, this vast army of the sons of Pandu, arranged in battle formation by your intelligent disciple, the son of Drupada.
verses.transliteration: paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṁ camūm vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
verses.meaning: Duryodhana directs Drona's attention to the formidable Pandava army, highlighting its strategic organization by Drupada's son, who was also Drona's student.

verses.sanskrit: अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि । युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥ ४ ॥
verses.translation: In this army are many heroic archers equal to Bhima and Arjuna in battle, including Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada, all great chariot warriors.
verses.transliteration: atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahā-rathaḥ
verses.meaning: Duryodhana identifies prominent warriors in the Pandava army, acknowledging their exceptional valor and skill in combat.

verses.sanskrit: धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् । पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥ ५ ॥
verses.translation: There are also Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya, the best among men.
verses.transliteration: dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ kāśirājaś ca vīryavān purujit kuntibhojaś ca śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ
verses.meaning: Duryodhana continues to list distinguished warriors in the Pandava army, emphasizing their strength and prowess.

verses.sanskrit: युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् । सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः ॥ ६ ॥
verses.translation: There are the mighty Yudhamanyu, the valiant Uttamauja, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi, all great chariot warriors.
verses.transliteration: yudhāmanyuś ca vikrānta uttamaujāś ca vīryavān saubhadro draupadeyāś ca sarva eva mahā-rathāḥ
verses.meaning: Duryodhana adds more names to the list of formidable Pandava warriors, recognizing their exceptional combat skills.

verses.sanskrit: अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम । नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते ॥ ७ ॥
verses.translation: O best of the twice-born, know also about the distinguished warriors on our side. Now I shall name the principal ones among them for your information.
verses.transliteration: asmākaṁ tu viśiṣṭā ye tānnibodha dvijottama nāyakā mama sainyasya saṁjñārtham tānbravīmi te
verses.meaning: Duryodhana shifts his focus to his own army, expressing his intention to inform Drona about its prominent warriors.

verses.sanskrit: भवान् भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिंजयः । अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च ॥ ८ ॥
verses.translation: There are yourself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, and Ashvatthama, the victorious in battle, as well as Vikarna, and the son of Somadatta.
verses.transliteration: bhavān bhīṣmaś ca karṇaś ca kṛpaś ca samitiṁ-jayaḥ aśvatthāmā vikarṇaś ca saumadattis tathaiva ca
verses.meaning: Duryodhana enumerates the key warriors on his side, acknowledging their renowned strength and combat expertise.

verses.sanskrit: अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः । नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः ॥ ९ ॥
verses.translation: And there are many other heroes who are prepared to lay down their lives for me, armed with various weapons and skilled in warfare.
verses.transliteration: anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ nānā-śastra-praharāṇāḥ sarve yuddha-viśāradāḥ
verses.meaning: Duryodhana emphasizes the presence of numerous other valiant warriors in his army, all dedicated to fighting for his cause.

verses.sanskrit: अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् । पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् ॥ १० ॥
verses.translation: Our strength is immeasurable, being protected by Bhishma, while their strength is limited, being protected by Bhima.
verses.transliteration: aparyāptaṁ tad asmākaṁ balaṁ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam paryāptaṁ tv idam eteṣāṁ balaṁ bhīmābhirakṣitam
verses.meaning: Duryodhana assesses the relative strengths of the two armies, expressing confidence in his own army's might due to Bhishma's protection.

verses.sanskrit: अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः । भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि ॥ ११ ॥
verses.translation: Therefore, all of you, stationed in your respective positions, give full support to Bhishma.
verses.transliteration: ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathā-bhāgam avasthitāḥ bhīṣmam evābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi
verses.meaning: Duryodhana instructs his commanders to strategically position themselves and provide unwavering support to Bhishma.

verses.sanskrit: तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः । सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् ॥ १२ ॥
verses.translation: Then Bhishma, the glorious grandsire of the Kurus, wishing to cheer Duryodhana, roared like a lion and blew his conchshell loudly.
verses.transliteration: tasya sañjanayan harṣaṁ kuru-vṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ siṁha-nādaṁ vinadyoccaiḥ śaṅkhaṁ dadhmau pratāpavān
verses.meaning: Bhishma, to boost Duryodhana's morale, roared like a lion and sounded his conchshell with great vigor.

verses.sanskrit: ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः । सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत् ॥ १३ ॥
verses.translation: After that, conchshells, kettledrums, tabors, drums, and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
verses.transliteration: tataḥ śaṅkhāś ca bheryaś ca paṇavānaka-gomukhāḥ sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdas tumulo 'bhavat
verses.meaning: The commencement of the battle was marked by the simultaneous sounding of various musical instruments, creating a deafening uproar.

verses.sanskrit: ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ । माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः ॥ १४ ॥
verses.translation: Then, situated in a great chariot drawn by white horses, Lord Krishna and Arjuna blew their celestial conchshells.
verses.transliteration: tataḥ śvetair hayair yukte mahati syandane sthitau mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaś caiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna and Arjuna, positioned in a magnificent chariot, heralded the start of the battle by blowing their divine conchshells.

verses.sanskrit: पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः । पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः ॥ १५ ॥
verses.translation: Krishna blew His conchshell, Panchajanya; Arjuna blew his, Devadatta; and Bhima of terrible deeds blew his great conchshell, Paundra.
verses.transliteration: pāñcajanyaṁ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṁ dhanañjayaḥ pauṇḍraṁ dadhmau mahā-śaṅkhaṁ bhīma-karmā vṛkodaraḥ
verses.meaning: The specific conchshells of Krishna, Arjuna, and Bhima are identified, each with its unique name, sounded to announce their presence.

verses.sanskrit: अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः । नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ ॥ १६ ॥
verses.translation: King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew his conchshell, Anantavijaya; and Nakula and Sahadeva blew Sughosha and Manipushpaka.
verses.transliteration: anantavijayaṁ rājā kuntī-putro yudhiṣṭhiraḥ nakulaḥ sahadevaś ca sughoṣamaṇipuṣpakau
verses.meaning: Yudhishthira, along with Nakula and Sahadeva, also blew their respective conchshells, each with distinct names.

verses.sanskrit: काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः । धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः ॥ १७ ॥
verses.translation: There were also the great archer, the king of Kashi, the great chariot warrior, Shikhandi, Dhristadyumna, Virata, and the invincible Satyaki.
verses.transliteration: kāśyaś ca parameṣvāsaḥ śikhaṇḍī ca mahā-rathaḥ dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaś ca sātyakiś cāparājitaḥ
verses.meaning: The conchshells of other prominent warriors in the Pandava army, known for their archery and combat skills, were also sounded.

verses.sanskrit: द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते । सुभद्रतनयश्चैव स्वं स्वं शङ्खं प्रदध्मुः ॥ १८ ॥
verses.translation: O king, Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, the son of Subhadra, and others, all blew their respective conchshells.
verses.transliteration: drupado draupadeyāś ca sarvaśaḥ pṛthivī-pate subhadra-tanayaś caiva svaṁ svaṁ śaṅkhaṁ pradadhmuḥ
verses.meaning: Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, Abhimanyu, and other warriors joined in the resounding declaration of war by blowing their conchshells.

verses.sanskrit: स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् । नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन् ॥ १९ ॥
verses.translation: The tumultuous sound produced by their conchshells pierced the hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra, filling the sky and the earth with its vibrations.
verses.transliteration: sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṁ hṛdayāni vyadārayat nabhaś ca pṛthivīṁ caiva tumulo vyanunādayan
verses.meaning: The combined sound of the conchshells created a deafening roar that shook the hearts of Dhritarashtra's sons and reverberated throughout the cosmos.

verses.sanskrit: अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान्कपिध्वजः । प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसम्पाते ह्येषीकेशमब्रवीत् ॥ २० ॥
verses.translation: At that time, seeing the sons of Dhritarashtra arrayed for battle, Arjuna, whose banner bore the emblem of Hanuman, spoke these words to Lord Krishna.
verses.transliteration: atha vyavasthitān dṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrān kapi-dhvajaḥ pravṛtte śastra-sampāte hṛṣīkeśam abravīt
verses.meaning: As the battle was about to commence, Arjuna, distinguished by the Hanuman emblem on his chariot, addressed Lord Krishna.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच । सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत ॥ २१ ॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Achyuta, place my chariot between the two armies.
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca senayor ubhayor madhye rathaṁ sthāpaya me 'cyuta
verses.meaning: Arjuna requests Krishna to position his chariot in the space between the opposing armies.

verses.sanskrit: यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् । कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन्समरकर्मणि ॥ २२ ॥
verses.translation: So that I may observe those standing here, eager to fight, and know with whom I must contend in this great battle.
verses.transliteration: yāvad etān nirīkṣe 'haṁ yoddhukāmān avasthitān kair mayā saha yoddhavyam asmin samara-karmaṇi
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his desire to see the warriors on both sides of the battlefield to assess the situation and determine his adversaries.

verses.sanskrit: योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः । धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः ॥ २३ ॥
verses.translation: Let me see those who have come here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.
verses.transliteration: yotsyamānān avekṣe 'haṁ ya ete 'tra samāgatāḥ dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddher yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavaḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna wants to see those who have gathered on the battlefield to support Duryodhana, whom he characterizes as evil-minded.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच । एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत । सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम् ॥ २४ ॥
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: O descendant of Bharata, having been thus addressed by Arjuna, Lord Krishna placed the excellent chariot between the two armies.
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca evam ukto hṛṣīkeśo guḍākeśena bhārata senayor ubhayor madhye sthāpayitvā rathottamam
verses.meaning: Sanjaya narrates how Krishna, upon hearing Arjuna's request, positioned the chariot between the opposing armies.

verses.sanskrit: भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम् । उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति ॥ २५ ॥
verses.translation: In front of Bhishma, Drona, and all the other rulers, Lord Krishna said, "Behold, O Arjuna, these assembled Kurus."
verses.transliteration: bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ sarveṣāṁ ca mahīkṣitām uvāca pārtha paśyaitān samavetān kurūn iti
verses.meaning: Krishna directed Arjuna's attention to the assembled Kuru warriors, including prominent figures like Bhishma and Drona.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितॄनथ पितामहान् । आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातॄन्पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा ॥ २६ ॥
verses.translation: There Arjuna saw, standing before him, fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.
verses.transliteration: tatrāpaśyat sthitān pārthaḥ pitṝn atha pitāmahān ācāryān mātulān bhrātṝn putrān pautrān sakhīṁs tathā
verses.meaning: Arjuna's gaze fell upon his relatives and respected elders present on the battlefield, including fathers, grandfathers, and teachers.

verses.sanskrit: श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि । तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान् ॥ २७ ॥
verses.translation: He saw his fathers-in-law and well-wishers in both armies. Seeing all these kinsmen standing before him, Arjuna,
verses.transliteration: śvaśurān suhṛdaś caiva senayor ubhayor api tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ sarvān bandhūn avasthitān
verses.meaning: Arjuna also recognized his fathers-in-law and friends in both armies, and the sight of all his relatives deeply affected him.

verses.sanskrit: कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् ॥ २८ ॥
verses.translation: was overwhelmed with great compassion, and spoke thus in his sorrow.
verses.transliteration: kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo viṣīdann idam abravīt
verses.meaning: Arjuna was overcome with profound sorrow and compassion, leading him to express his anguish.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच । दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपास्थितम् ॥ २९ ॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, seeing my own kinsmen gathered here with the desire to fight,
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca dṛṣṭvemaṁ sva-janaṁ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṁ samupāsthitam
verses.meaning: Arjuna begins to speak, expressing his distress at the sight of his relatives assembled for battle.

verses.sanskrit: सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति । वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते ॥ ३० ॥
verses.translation: My limbs fail me, my mouth is drying up, my body trembles, and my hair is standing on end.
verses.transliteration: sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati vepathuś ca śarīre me romaharṣaś ca jāyate
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the physical symptoms of his emotional distress, including weakness, dryness, and trembling.

verses.sanskrit: गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते । न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः ॥ ३१ ॥
verses.translation: The bow slips from my hand, my skin is burning, I am unable even to stand, and my mind seems to be reeling.
verses.transliteration: gāṇḍīvaṁ sraṁsate hastāt tvak caiva paridahyate na ca śaknomy avasthātuṁ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna's distress intensifies, causing his bow to slip and his mind to become অস্থির and confused.

verses.sanskrit: निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव । न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे ॥ ३२ ॥
verses.translation: O Keshava, I see inauspicious omens, and I do not see any good in killing my own kinsmen in this battle.
verses.transliteration: nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni keśava na ca śreyo 'nupaśyāmi hatvā sva-janam āhave
verses.meaning: Arjuna observes unfavorable omens and expresses his conviction that killing his relatives in battle will not lead to any good.

verses.sanskrit: न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च । किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा ॥ ३३ ॥
verses.translation: I do not desire victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures. O Govinda, what is the use of kingdom, or enjoyment, or even life itself?
verses.transliteration: na kāṅkṣe vijayaṁ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṁ sukhāni ca kiṁ no rājyena govinda kiṁ bhogair jīvitena vā
verses.meaning: Arjuna questions the value of victory, kingdom, and worldly pleasures in light of the impending violence against his kin.

verses.sanskrit: येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च । त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च ॥ ३४ ॥
verses.translation: For whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures, they stand here in battle, having renounced their lives and wealth.
verses.transliteration: yeṣām arthe kāṅkṣitaṁ no rājyaṁ bhogāḥ sukhāni ca ta ime 'vasthitā yuddhe prāṇāṁs tyaktvā dhanāni ca
verses.meaning: Arjuna reflects on the irony of fighting against those for whom he desires prosperity andhappiness.

verses.sanskrit: आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः ।मातुलाः श्वशुराःपौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा ॥ ३५ ॥
verses.translation: Teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives.
verses.transliteration: ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrās tathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ śyālāḥ sambandhinas tathā
verses.meaning: Arjuna lists the various family relations present on the battlefield, emphasizing the depth of his familial ties.

verses.sanskrit: एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन । अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते ॥ ३६ ॥
verses.translation: These I do not wish to kill, though they may slay me, O Madhusudana, even for the sake of sovereignty over the three worlds, what to speak of this earthly kingdom?
verses.transliteration: etān na hantum icchāmi ghnato 'pi madhusūdana api trailokya-rājyasya hetoḥ kiṁ nu mahī-kṛte
verses.meaning: Arjuna declares his unwillingness to kill his relatives, even for the sake of ruling the three worlds, let alone a mere earthly kingdom.

verses.sanskrit: निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन । पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः ॥ ३७ ॥
verses.translation: O Janardana, what pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhritarashtra? Sin only will accrue to us by slaying these aggressors.
verses.transliteration: nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrān naḥ kā prītiḥ syāj janārdana pāpam evāśrayed asmān hatvaitān ātatāyinaḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna questions the value of victory if it comes at the cost of killing his relatives, fearing the karmic consequences.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् । स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ॥ ३८ ॥
verses.translation: Therefore, we ought not to kill our cousins, the sons of Dhritarashtra, and our kinsmen. O Madhava, how can we be happy by killing our own people?
verses.transliteration: tasmān nārhā vayaṁ hantuṁ dhārtarāṣṭrān sva-bāndhavān sva-janaṁ hi kathaṁ hatvā সুখিনঃ syāma mādhava
verses.meaning: Arjuna reiterates his conviction that killing his relatives will not lead to happiness and argues against engaging in such an act.

verses.sanskrit: यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः । कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् ॥ ३९ ॥
verses.translation: Though their minds are overpowered by greed, they see no evil in the destruction of their family or sin in hostility towards friends.
verses.transliteration: yadyapy ete na paśyanti lobhopahata-cetasaḥ kula-kṣaya-kṛtaṁ doṣaṁ mitra-drohe ca pātakam
verses.meaning: Arjuna acknowledges that the opposing side, driven by greed, fails to perceive theAdharmic nature of their actions.

verses.sanskrit: कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् । कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन ॥ ४० ॥
verses.translation: O Janardana, why should we, who clearly see the evil in the destruction of a family, not turn away from this sin?
verses.transliteration: kathaṁ na jñeyam asmābhiḥ pāpād asmān nivartitum kula-kṣaya-kṛtaṁ doṣaṁ prapaśyadbhir janārdana
verses.meaning: Arjuna questions why he and his side, who understand the consequences, should not refrain from this sinful act.

verses.sanskrit: कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः । धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत ॥ ४१ ॥
verses.translation: With the destruction of the family, the eternal family traditions are destroyed, and with the destruction of traditions, lawlessness overwhelms the whole family.
verses.transliteration: kula-kṣaye praṇaśyanti kula-dharmāḥ sanātanāḥ dharme naṣṭe kulaṁ kṛtsnam adharmo 'bhibhavaty uta
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the social and spiritual consequences of family destruction, including the loss of traditions and the rise of lawlessness.

verses.sanskrit: अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः । स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः ॥ ४२ ॥
verses.translation: With the prevalence of lawlessness, O Krishna, the women of the family become corrupted; and with the corruption of women, there arises intermingling of castes.
verses.transliteration: adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya jāyate varṇa-saṅkaraḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna explains how social order is disrupted by Adharma, leading to the corruption of women and the mixing of castes.

verses.sanskrit: सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च । पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः ॥ ४३ ॥
verses.translation: This intermingling leads the family and the destroyers of the family to hell; for the ancestors fall, deprived of the offerings of food and water.
verses.transliteration: saṅkaro narakaāyaiva kula-ghnānāṁ kulasya ca patanti pitaro hy eṣāṁ lupta-piṇḍodaka-kriyāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna warns of the dire consequences of caste mixing, including hell for the family and its destroyers, and the suffering of ancestors.

verses.sanskrit: दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः । उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः ॥ ४४ ॥
verses.translation: By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which cause intermingling of castes, the eternal traditions of the family and the community are destroyed.
verses.transliteration: doṣair etaiḥ kula-ghnānāṁ varṇa-saṅkara-kārakaiḥ utsādyante jāti-dharmāḥ kula-dharmāś ca śāśvatāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna highlights how the destruction of family leads to the destruction of both family and community traditions.

verses.sanskrit: उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन । नरके नियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम ॥ ४५ ॥
verses.translation: O Janardana, I have heard that those men whose family traditions are destroyed dwell in hell for a long time.
verses.transliteration: utsanna-kula-dharmāṇāṁ manuṣyāṇāṁ janārdana narake niyataṁ vāso bhavatīty anuśuśruma
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his understanding that those who destroy family traditions are destined for hell.

verses.sanskrit: अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् । यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः ॥ ४६ ॥
verses.translation: Alas! What a great sin we are about to commit, that we are prepared to kill our own kinsmen, motivated by the desire for kingdom and pleasure.
verses.transliteration: aho bata mahat pāpaṁ kartuṁ vyavasitā vayam yad rājya-sukha-lobhena hantuṁ sva-janam udyatāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna laments the grave sin he is about to commit by being willing to kill his relatives for a kingdom.

verses.sanskrit: यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः । धार्तराष्ट्रा हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत् ॥ ४७ ॥
verses.translation: If the sons of Dhritarashtra, with weapons in their hands, were to kill me, unarmed and unresisting on the battlefield, that would be better for me.
verses.transliteration: yadi mām apratīkāram aśastraṁ śastra-pāṇayaḥ dhārtarāṣṭrā hanyus tan me kṣemataram bhavet
verses.meaning: Arjuna concludes that it would be preferable to be killed unarmed than to kill his relatives in battle.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच । एवमुक्त्वार्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत् । विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः ॥ ४८ ॥
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus on the battlefield, Arjuna cast aside his bow and arrows, and sat down on the seat of the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow.
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca evam uktvārjunaḥ saṅkhye rathopastha upāviśat visṛjya sa-śaraṁ cāpaṁ śoka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ
verses.meaning: Sanjaya narrates how, after expressing his anguish, Arjuna throws down his weapons and sits down in his chariot, consumed by grief.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच । तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम् । विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः ॥ १ ॥
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: To him, thus overwhelmed with compassion, his eyes filled with tears and downcast, the Lord spoke these words.
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca taṁ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭam aśru-pūrṇākulekṣaṇam viṣīdantam idaṁ vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ
verses.meaning: Sanjaya describes Krishna's response to Arjuna's state of distress and sorrow on the battlefield.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच । कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम् । अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन ॥ २ ॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Whence has this dejection come upon you in this crisis? This is not befitting a noble person. It does not lead to heaven, but to infamy, O Arjuna.
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṁ viṣame samupasthitam anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrti-karam arjuna
verses.meaning: Krishna questions Arjuna about the inappropriateness of his despondency in the face of battle, emphasizing that it is unbecoming of a warrior.

verses.sanskrit: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते । क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप ॥ ३ ॥
verses.translation: Yield not to unmanliness, O son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Abandon this petty weakness of heart and arise, O scorcher of enemies.
verses.transliteration: klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate kṣudraṁ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṁ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa
verses.meaning: Krishna urges Arjuna to cast aside his weakness and cowardice, and to rise up and fulfill his duty as a warrior.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच । कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन । इषुभिः प्रति योत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन ॥ ४ ॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Madhusudana, how can I fight with arrows in battle against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of my reverence, O slayer of enemies?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca kathaṁ bhīṣmam ahaṁ saṅkhye droṇaṁ ca madhusūdana iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his moral dilemma about fighting against revered elders like Bhishma and Drona.

verses.sanskrit: गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्षमपीह लोके । हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् ॥ ५ ॥
verses.translation: It would be better to live on alms in this world than to slay these noble teachers. But if I kill them, my gain will be the enjoyment of wealth and pleasures stained with their blood.
verses.transliteration: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṁ bhaikṣam apīha loke hatvā'rtha-kāmāṁs tu gurūn ihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān
verses.meaning: Arjuna believes that it is preferable to live as a beggar than to kill his teachers for worldly gain, which would be tainted with blood.

verses.sanskrit: न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः । यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामस्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः ॥ ६ ॥
verses.translation: We do not even know which is better for us—whether we should conquer them or they should conquer us. Before us stand the sons of Dhritarashtra, by killing whom we would not even wish to live.
verses.transliteration: na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te 'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna is uncertain about the outcome of the battle and expresses his reluctance to kill Dhritarashtra's sons, as he values life more than victory in such a conflict.

verses.sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः । यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् ॥ ७ ॥
verses.translation: Now I am confused about my duty and have lost all composure because of miserly weakness. In this condition I am asking You to tell me clearly what is best for me. Now I am Your disciple, and a soul surrendered unto You. Please instruct me.
verses.transliteration: kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharma-sammūḍha-cetāḥ yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṁ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te 'haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam
verses.meaning: Arjuna, overwhelmed by weakness and confusion about his duty (dharma), seeks guidance from Krishna, acknowledging Him as his teacher and surrendering to Him for instruction.

verses.sanskrit: न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् । अवाप्य भूमावसপত্নमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् ॥ ८ ॥
verses.translation: I can find no means to drive away this grief which is drying up my senses. I will not be able to dispel it even if I win a prosperous, unrivaled kingdom on the earth with sovereignty like the demigods in heaven.
verses.transliteration: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṁ rājyaṁ surāṇām api cādhipatyam
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his inability to overcome his sorrow, even with the prospect of gaining a prosperous and unrivaled kingdom on Earth or dominion over the gods.

verses.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच । एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप । न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह ॥ ९ ॥
verses.translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Lord Krishna, Arjuna, the chastiser of enemies, said, "O Govinda, I shall not fight," and became silent.
verses.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṁ guḍākeśaḥ parantapaḥ na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṁ babhūva ha
verses.meaning: Sanjaya recounts how Arjuna, after speaking to Krishna, declares his decision not to fight and falls silent.

verses.sanskrit: तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत । सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः ॥ १० ॥
verses.translation: O descendant of Bharata, at that time Lord Krishna, smiling as it were, spoke the following words to the grief-stricken Arjuna in the midst of both the armies.
verses.transliteration: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṁ vacaḥ
verses.meaning: Sanjaya describes Krishna's demeanor as he begins to address Arjuna, who is overwhelmed with grief in the middle of the battlefield.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच । अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे । गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ॥ ११ ॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: While speaking learned words, you are mourning for what is not worthy of grief. Those who are wise lament neither for the living nor for the dead.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṁ prajñā-vādāṁś ca bhāṣase gatāsūn agatāsūṁś ca na anuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna begins his teaching by pointing out the contradiction in Arjuna's words and actions, stating that true wisdom lies in not grieving for the perishable.

verses.sanskrit: न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः । न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् ॥ १२ ॥
verses.translation: Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor all these kings; nor in the future shall any of us cease to be.
verses.transliteration: na tv evāhaṁ jātu nāsaṁ na tvaṁ neme janādhipāḥ na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the eternal nature of the soul, asserting that neither He, Arjuna, nor the kings ever did not exist, nor will they cease to exist in the future.

verses.sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन् यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा । तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति ॥ १३ ॥
verses.translation: As the embodied soul continuously passes, in this body, from boyhood to youth to old age, the soul similarly passes into another body at the time of death. The wise are not bewildered by this.
verses.transliteration: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā tathā dehāntara-prāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
verses.meaning: Krishna uses the analogy of bodily changes to explain the transmigration of the soul, emphasizing that a wise person is not deluded by this process.

verses.sanskrit: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः । आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत ॥ १४ ॥
verses.translation: O son of Kunti, the nonpermanent appearance of happiness and distress, and their disappearance in due course, are like the appearance and disappearance of winter and summer seasons. They arise from sense perception, O scion of Bharata, and one must learn to tolerate them without being disturbed.
verses.transliteration: mātrā-sparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkhadāḥ āgamāpāyino 'nityās tāṁs titikṣasva bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to tolerate the dualities of happiness and distress, which are temporary and arise from sense perception, comparing them to the changing seasons.

verses.sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ । समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते ॥ १५ ॥
verses.translation: O best among men [Arjuna], the person who is not disturbed by happiness and distress and is steady in both is certainly eligible for liberation.
verses.transliteration: yaṁ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ dhīraṁ so 'mṛtatvāya kalpate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of a liberated person, who remains undisturbed by the dualities of life and is equipoised in happiness and distress.

verses.sanskrit: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः । उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः ॥ १६ ॥
verses.translation: Those who are seers of the truth have concluded that of the nonexistent [the material body] there is no endurance and of the eternal [the soul] there is no change. This they have concluded by studying the nature of both.
verses.transliteration: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ ubhayor api dṛṣṭo 'ntas tv anayos tattva-darśibhiḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna distinguishes between the temporary nature of the material body and the eternal nature of the soul, as understood by the seers of truth.

verses.sanskrit: अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् । विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति ॥ १७ ॥
verses.translation: Know that which pervades the entire body is indestructible. No one is able to destroy that imperishable soul.
verses.transliteration: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṁ tatam vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the indestructible nature of the soul that pervades the entire body, stating that no one can destroy it.

verses.sanskrit: अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः । अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत ॥ १८ ॥
verses.translation: Only the material bodies of the indestructible, immeasurable, and eternal living entity are subject to destruction. Therefore, fight, O descendant of Bharata.
verses.transliteration: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ anāśino 'prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna clarifies that only the bodies are perishable, while the soul is eternal. Therefore, Arjuna should fight without concern for the destruction of the bodies.

verses.sanskrit: य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् । उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते ॥ १९ ॥
verses.translation: Neither he who thinks the living entity the slayer nor he who thinks it slain is in knowledge, for the self slays not nor is slain.
verses.transliteration: ya enaṁ vetti hantāraṁ yaś cainaṁ manyate hatam ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṁ hanti na hanyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that the soul is neither the slayer nor the slain, and thus, one who understands this does not truly kill or get killed.

verses.sanskrit: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः । अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे ॥ २० ॥
verses.translation: For the soul there is neither birth nor death at any time. He has not come into being, does not come into being, and will not come into being. He is unborn, eternal, ever-existing and primeval. He is not slain when the body is slain.
verses.transliteration: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṁ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
verses.meaning: Krishna further elaborates on the eternal nature of the soul, emphasizing that it is unborn, immortal, and indestructible, even when the body is destroyed.

verses.sanskrit: वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् । कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् ॥ २१ ॥
verses.translation: O Partha, how can a person who knows that the soul is indestructible, eternal, unborn and immutable kill anyone or cause anyone to kill?
verses.transliteration: vedāvināśinaṁ nityaṁ ya enam ajam avyayam kathaṁ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṁ ghātayati hanti kam
verses.meaning: Krishna questions Arjuna, asking how someone who understands the true nature of the soul can be an agent of killing or cause another to be killed.

verses.sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि । तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णान्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही ॥ २२ ॥
verses.translation: As a person puts on new garments, giving up old ones, the soul similarly accepts new material bodies, giving up the old and useless ones.
verses.transliteration: vāsāṁsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro 'parāṇi tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāny anyāni saṁyāti navāni dehī
verses.meaning: Krishna uses the analogy of changing clothes to illustrate how the soul transmigrates from one body to another, discarding old ones for new.

verses.sanskrit: नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः । न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः ॥ २३ ॥
verses.translation: The soul can never be cut to pieces by any weapon, nor burned by fire, nor moistened by water, nor withered by the wind.
verses.transliteration: nainaṁ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṁ dahati pāvakaḥ na cainaṁ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the indestructible nature of the soul, stating that it cannot be harmed by any material element.

verses.sanskrit: अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च । नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः ॥ २४ ॥
verses.translation: This individual soul is unbreakable and insoluble, and can be neither burned nor dried. He is everlasting, present everywhere, unchangeable, immovable and eternally the same.
verses.transliteration: acchedyo 'yam adāhyo 'yam akledyo 'śoṣya eva ca nityaḥ sarva-gataḥ sthāṇur acalo 'yaṁ sanātanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna further emphasizes the eternal, all-pervading, and immutable nature of the soul.

verses.sanskrit: अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते । तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि ॥ २५ ॥
verses.translation: It is said that the soul is invisible, inconceivable and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve for the body.
verses.transliteration: avyakto 'yam acintyo 'yam avikāryo 'yam ucyate tasmād evaṁ viditvainaṁ nānuśocitum arhasi
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes that since the soul is imperceptible and unchanging, there is no reason to grieve for the perishable body.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम् । तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥ २६ ॥
verses.translation: If, however, you think that the soul [or the symptoms of life] is always born and dies forever, you still have no reason to lament, O mighty-armed.
verses.transliteration: atha cainaṁ nitya-jātaṁ nityaṁ vā manyase mṛtam tathāpi tvaṁ mahā-bāho naivaṁ śocitum arhasi
verses.meaning: Krishna addresses a hypothetical argument, stating that even if the soul were subject to birth and death, there would still be no reason to grieve.

verses.sanskrit: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च । तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥ २७ ॥
verses.translation: For one who has taken his birth, death is certain; and for one who is dead, birth is certain. Therefore, in the unavoidable discharge of your duty, you should not lament.
verses.transliteration: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṁ janma mṛtasya ca tasmād aparihārye 'rthe na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the inevitability of birth and death, emphasizing that it is part of one's duty to accept this natural cycle without grief.

verses.sanskrit: अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत । अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना ॥ २८ ॥
verses.translation: All created beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their interim state, and unmanifest again when annihilated. So what need is there for lamentation?
verses.transliteration: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata avyakta-nidhanāny eva tatra kā paridevanā
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the cycle of existence, noting that beings are unmanifest before birth, manifest during life, and unmanifest again after death, suggesting there's no reason to lament this natural process.

verses.sanskrit: आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनमाश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः । आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् ॥ २९ ॥
verses.translation: Some look on the soul as amazing, some describe him as amazing, and some hear of him as amazing, while others, even after hearing about him, cannot understand him at all.
verses.transliteration: āścarya-vat paśyati kaścid enam āścarya-vad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ āścarya-vac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrutvāpy enaṁ veda na caiva kaścit
verses.meaning: Krishna highlights the difficulty in comprehending the true nature of the soul, stating that it is seen, spoken, and heard of as amazing, and yet, many do not understand it.

verses.sanskrit: देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत । तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥ ३० ॥
verses.translation: O descendant of Bharata, he who dwells in the body can never be slain. Therefore you need not grieve for any living being.
verses.transliteration: dehī nityam avadhyo 'yaṁ dehe sarvasya bhārata tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi
verses.meaning: Krishna reiterates the eternal and indestructible nature of the soul within the body, urging Arjuna not to grieve for any living being.

verses.sanskrit: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि । धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते ॥ ३१ ॥
verses.translation: Considering your specific duty as a kshatriya, you should know that there is no better engagement for you than fighting on religious principles; and so there is no need for hesitation.
verses.transliteration: sva-dharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi dharmyāddhi yuddhāc chreyo 'nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
verses.meaning: Krishna reminds Arjuna of his duty as a Kshatriya to fight for righteousness, stating that there is no higher path for him than this.

verses.sanskrit: यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् । सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् ॥ ३२ ॥
verses.translation: O Partha, happy are the kshatriyas to whom such a fight comes of its own accord, opening for them the doors of the heavenly planets.
verses.transliteration: yadṛcchayā copapannaṁ svarga-dvāram apāvṛtam sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes fighting for a righteous cause as a fortunate opportunity for a Kshatriya, leading to heavenly rewards.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि । ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥ ३३ ॥
verses.translation: If, however, you do not perform your religious duty of fighting in this righteous war, then you will certainly incur sins for neglecting your duties and thus lose your reputation as a fighter.
verses.transliteration: atha cet tvam imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṁgrāmaṁ na kariṣyasi tataḥ sva-dharmaṁ kīrtiṁ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna warns Arjuna that failing to fulfill his duty will result in sin and loss of reputation.

verses.sanskrit: अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् । संभावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते ॥ ३४ ॥
verses.translation: People will always speak of your infamy, and for a respectable person, dishonor is worse than death.
verses.transliteration: akīrtiṁ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te 'vyayām sambhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the importance of honor, stating that infamy is worse than death for a respectable person like Arjuna.

verses.sanskrit: भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः । येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् ॥ ३५ ॥
verses.translation: The great generals who have highly esteemed your name and fame will think that you have left the battlefield out of fear only, and thus they will consider you insignificant.
verses.transliteration: bhayād raṇād uparataṁ maṁsyante tvāṁ mahā-rathāḥ yeṣāṁ ca tvaṁ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that Arjuna's retreat from battle would be perceived as cowardice by his esteemed peers, leading to a loss of respect.

verses.sanskrit: अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः । ततो दुःखतरं किं नु तत् ॥ ३६ ॥
verses.translation: Your enemies will speak many unkind words about you and further deride your ability. What could be more painful for you?
verses.transliteration: avācya-vādāṁś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ tato duḥkha-taraṁ kiṁ nu tat
verses.meaning: Krishna points out that Arjuna's enemies will seize the opportunity to speak ill of him, causing him immense pain.

verses.sanskrit: हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् । तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः ॥ ३७ ॥
verses.translation: O son of Kunti, either you will be killed in the battle and attain the heavenly planets, or you will conquer and enjoy the earthly kingdom. Therefore, arise with determination to fight.
verses.transliteration: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṁ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna encourages Arjuna to fight with resolve, reminding him that either outcome—death or victory—will be favorable for a Kshatriya.

verses.sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ । ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥ ३८ ॥
verses.translation: Do thou fight for the sake of fighting, without considering happiness or distress, loss or gain, victory or defeat—and by so doing you shall never incur sin.
verses.transliteration: sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to fight without attachment to the results, treating both favorable and unfavorable outcomes with equanimity, thus avoiding sin.

verses.sanskrit: एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु । बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि ॥ ३९ ॥
verses.translation: Thus far I have described this knowledge to you through analytical study. Now listen to Me as I explain it in the mode of action. O son of Pritha, if you act in such knowledge, you can free yourself from the bondage of works.
verses.transliteration: eṣā te 'bhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṁ śṛṇu buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karma-bandhaṁ prahāsyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna transitions from explaining the soul's nature (Sankhya) to the path of action (Yoga), promising Arjuna liberation from karmic bondage through this knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते । स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् ॥ ४० ॥
verses.translation: In this endeavor there is no loss or diminution, and a little advancement on this path can protect one from the most dangerous type of fear.
verses.transliteration: nehābhikrama-nāśo 'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the unique benefit of selfless action (Yoga), stating that even a small effort brings lasting benefit and protection from great danger.

verses.sanskrit: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन । बहुशाखायनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ॥ ४१ ॥
verses.translation: Those who are on this path are resolute in purpose, and their aim is one. O beloved child of the Kurus, the intelligence of those who are irresolute is many-branched.
verses.transliteration: vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana bahu-śākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayo 'vyavasāyinām
verses.meaning: Krishna contrasts the focused determination of those on the path of Yoga with the scattered and indecisive minds of those who are not.

verses.sanskrit: यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः । वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः ॥ ४२ ॥
verses.translation: Men of small knowledge are very much attached to the flowery words of the Vedas, which recommend various fruitive activities for elevation to heavenly planets, resultant good birth, power, and so forth. Being desirous of sense gratification and prosperous lives, they say that there is nothing more than this.
verses.transliteration: yām imāṁ puṣpitāṁ vācaṁ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ veda-vāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna criticizes those who are attached to the superficial aspects of the Vedas, focusing on rituals for material gain and ignoring the higher purpose of spiritual realization.

verses.sanskrit: कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् । क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति ॥ ४३ ॥
verses.translation: They are full of desires, and they aim at the attainment of heavenly happiness and fruitful activities. As a result, they take birth again and again in this world.
verses.transliteration: kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām kriyā-viśeṣa-bahulāṁ bhogaiśvarya-gatiṁ prati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the cycle of rebirth that such people undergo, driven by their desires for worldly pleasures and the fruits of their actions.

verses.sanskrit: भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् । व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते ॥ ४४ ॥
verses.translation: In the minds of those who are too attached to sense enjoyment and material opulence, and who are bewildered by such teachings, the resolute determination for devotional service to the Supreme Lord does not take place.
verses.transliteration: bhogaiśvarya-prasaktānāṁ tayāpahṛta-cetasām vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that those who are engrossed in material pursuits are unable to develop the focused determination needed for spiritual realization.

verses.sanskrit: त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन । निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् ॥ ४५ ॥
verses.translation: The Vedas deal mainly with the subject of the three modes of material nature. O Arjuna, become transcendental to these three modes. Be free from all dualities and from all anxieties for gain and safety, and be established in the self.
verses.transliteration: traiguṇya-viṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kṣema ātmavān
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to transcend the three modes of material nature and the dualities of life, and to be established in the eternal self.

verses.sanskrit: यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके । तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः ॥ ४६ ॥
verses.translation: All purposes served by a small well can at once be served by the great reservoirs of water. Similarly, all the purposes of the Vedas can be fulfilled by one who knows the purpose behind them.
verses.transliteration: yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna uses the analogy of a well and a large reservoir to illustrate that a true understanding of the Vedas' purpose makes the rituals less important.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्यवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन । मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि ॥ ४७ ॥
verses.translation: You have a right to perform your prescribed duty, but you are not entitled to the fruits of action. Never consider yourself the cause of the results of your activities, and never be attached to not doing your duty.
verses.transliteration: karmaṇy-evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stv akarmaṇi
verses.meaning: Krishna outlines the principle of selfless action, emphasizing that one should focus on performing their duty without attachment to the results.

verses.sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय । सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ॥ ४८ ॥
verses.translation: Perform your duty equipoised, O Arjuna, abandoning all attachment to success or failure. Such equanimity is called yoga.
verses.transliteration: yoga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna defines Yoga as equanimity, advising Arjuna to perform his duties with detachment and even-mindedness in both success and failure.

verses.sanskrit: दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय । बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः ॥ ४९ ॥
verses.translation: O Dhananjaya, keep all abominable activities far distant by devotional service, and in that consciousness surrender unto the Lord. Those who want to enjoy the fruits of their work are misers.
verses.transliteration: dūreṇa hy avaraṁ karma buddhi-yogād dhanañjaya buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala-hetavaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna contrasts selfless action (Buddhi-yoga) with actions motivated by desire for rewards, describing the latter as inferior and those who perform them as misers.

verses.sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभौ सुकृतदुष्कृते । तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् ॥ ५० ॥
verses.translation: Even in this life, a man who is engaged in devotional service rids himself of the reactions to both good and bad actions. Therefore, strive for yoga, which is the art of all work.
verses.transliteration: buddhi-yukto jahātīha ubhau sukṛta-duṣkṛte tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
verses.meaning: Krishna highlights the purifying effect of selfless action (Yoga), stating that it frees one from the cycle of good and bad karma, and defines Yoga as the skill in action.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः । जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् ॥ ५१ ॥
verses.translation: By thus engaging in devotional service to the Lord, great sages or devotees free themselves from the results of work in the material world. In this way they become free from the cycle of birth and death and attain the state beyond all miseries [by going back to Godhead].
verses.transliteration: karma-jaṁ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṁ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ padaṁ gacchanty anāmayam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the liberation attained by those who perform selfless service, emphasizing their freedom from the cycle of birth and death and their attainment of a state of eternal bliss.

verses.sanskrit: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति । तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च ॥ ५२ ॥
verses.translation: When your intelligence has passed out of the dense forest of delusion, you shall become indifferent to all that has been heard and all that is to be heard.
verses.transliteration: yadā te moha-kalilaṁ buddhir vyatitariṣyati tadā gantāsi nirvedaṁ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that when one's intelligence is purified from delusion, they become indifferent to the cycle of hearing about and seeking worldly knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला । समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि ॥ ५३ ॥
verses.translation: When your mind is no longer disturbed by the flowery language of the Vedas, and when it remains fixed in trance, then you will have attained the divine consciousness.
verses.transliteration: śruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the state of স্থির intelligence, where the mind is unwavering and fixed in divine consciousness, leading to the attainment of Yoga.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच । स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव । स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् ॥ ५४ ॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what are the symptoms of one of steady intelligence or transcendental consciousness? How does he speak, and what is his language? How does he sit, and how does he walk?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi-sthasya keśava sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
verses.meaning: Arjuna inquires about the characteristics of a person with steady wisdom, seeking to understand their behavior and state of being.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच । प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान् । आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते ॥ ५५ ॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: O Partha, when a man gives up all varieties of sense desire which arise from mental concoction, and when his mind finds satisfaction in the self alone, then he is said to be in pure transcendental consciousness.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita-prajñas tadocyate
verses.meaning: Krishna defines a person of steady wisdom as one who has abandoned all desires and finds satisfaction in the self.

verses.sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः । वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ॥ ५६ ॥
verses.translation: One whose mind remains undisturbed even in the midst of the greatest suffering, who does not hanker after happiness, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger, is called a sage of steady mind.
verses.transliteration: duḥkheṣv anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a sage of steady mind as one who is equipoised in suffering and happiness, and free from negative emotions.

verses.sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् । नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥ ५७ ॥
verses.translation: In the material world, one who is unaffected by good or evil he may obtain, neither praising it nor despising it, is firmly fixed in perfect knowledge.
verses.transliteration: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tat tat prāpya śubhāśubham nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.meaning: Krishna further explains that a person of steady wisdom is unattached to both good and evil, neither rejoicing in the former nor hating the latter.

verses.sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः । इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥ ५८ ॥
verses.translation: One who is able to withdraw his senses from sense objects, as the tortoise draws his limbs within his shell, is firmly fixed in perfect consciousness.
verses.transliteration: yadā saṁharate cāyaṁ kūrmo 'ṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.meaning: Krishna uses the analogy of a tortoise withdrawing its limbs to illustrate how a person of steady wisdom withdraws their senses from sense objects.

verses.sanskrit: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः । रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते ॥ ५९ ॥
verses.translation: The embodied soul may be restricted from sense enjoyment, though the taste for sense objects remains. But, ceasing such engagements by experiencing a higher taste, he is fixed in consciousness.
verses.transliteration: viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ rasa-varjaṁ raso 'py asya paraṁ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that while sense objects may be renounced, the desire for them remains until a higher taste is experienced, leading to true detachment.

verses.sanskrit: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः । इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः ॥ ६० ॥
verses.translation: The senses are so strong and impetuous, O Arjuna, that they forcibly carry away the mind even of a man of discrimination who is endeavoring to control them.
verses.transliteration: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna acknowledges the power of the senses, stating that they can even distract a discerning person who is trying to control them.

verses.sanskrit: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः । वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥ ६१ ॥
verses.translation: One who restrains his senses, keeping them under full control, and fixes his consciousness upon Me, is known as a man of steady intelligence.
verses.transliteration: tāni sarvāṇi saṁyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the importance of complete sense control and fixing one's consciousness on Him as the means to attain steady intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते । सङ्गात्संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ॥ ६२ ॥
verses.translation: While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment for them, and from such attachment lust develops, and from lust anger arises.
verses.transliteration: dhyāyato viṣayān puṁsaḥ saṅgas teṣūpajāyate saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho 'bhijāyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the downward spiral that begins with contemplating sense objects, leading to attachment, lust, and anger.

verses.sanskrit: क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः । स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति ॥ ६३ ॥
verses.translation: From anger, complete delusion arises, and from delusion, bewilderment of memory. When memory is bewildered, intelligence is lost, and when intelligence is lost, one falls down again into the material pool.
verses.transliteration: krodhād bhavati sammohaḥ sammohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ smṛti-bhraṁśād buddhi-nāśo buddhi-nāśāt praṇaśyati
verses.meaning: Krishna continues to explain how anger leads to delusion, loss of memory, destruction of intelligence, and ultimately, spiritual downfall.

verses.sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् । आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति ॥ ६४ ॥
verses.translation: But a person free from attachment and aversion, who controls the senses through regulated freedom, attains the peace of Self-realization.
verses.transliteration: rāga-dveṣa-viyuktais tu viṣayān indriyaiś caran ātma-vaśyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigacchati
verses.meaning: This verse describes how one can attain peace by controlling the senses and freeing oneself from attachment and aversion.

verses.sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते । प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते ॥ ६५ ॥
verses.translation: In that peace, all sorrows are destroyed; for the intellect of the self-controlled person is soon firmly established in God.
verses.transliteration: prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir asyopajāyate prasanna-cetaso hy āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
verses.meaning: This verse explains that with inner peace, all sorrows are destroyed, and the intellect becomes firmly established in God.

verses.sanskrit: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना । न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् ॥ ६६ ॥
verses.translation: The uncontrolled person has no transcendental knowledge, there is no steady wisdom, and without that there is no peace. And how can there be any happiness without peace?
verses.transliteration: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
verses.meaning: This verse highlights the importance of self-control for attaining wisdom, peace, and happiness.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते । तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि ॥ ६७ ॥
verses.translation: As a boat on the water is swept away by a strong wind, even one of the roaming senses to which the mind is attached can carry away a person's intelligence.
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇāṁ hi caratāṁ yan mano 'nuvidhīyate tad asya harati prajñāṁ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi
verses.meaning: This verse uses the analogy of a boat in a storm to illustrate how uncontrolled senses can lead to the loss of wisdom.

verses.sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः । इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥ ६८ ॥
verses.translation: Therefore, O mighty-armed, one whose senses are completely restrained from their objects has steady intelligence.
verses.transliteration: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.meaning: This verse concludes that true wisdom comes from the complete control of the senses.

verses.sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी । यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः ॥ ६९ ॥
verses.translation: What is night for all beings is the time of awakening for the self-controlled; and what is the time of awakening for all beings is night for the introspective sage.
verses.transliteration: yā niśā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti saṁyamī yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ
verses.meaning: This verse describes the paradoxical nature of spiritual perception, where the self-controlled are awake to the reality that others are not.

verses.sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठमसमुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत् । तद्वत्काम यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी ॥ ७० ॥
verses.translation: A person who is not disturbed by the incessant flow of desires—that enter like rivers into the ocean, which is ever being filled but is always still—can alone achieve peace, and not the man who strives to satisfy such desires.
verses.transliteration: āpūryamāṇam acala-pratiṣṭham samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat tadvat kāmā yaṁ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī
verses.meaning: This verse uses the analogy of the ocean to illustrate that true peace comes when one is undisturbed by the influx of desires, not by trying to fulfill them.

verses.sanskrit: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः । निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति ॥ ७१ ॥
verses.translation: A person who has given up all desires for sense gratification, who longs for nothing, who is selfless and without any false conception of self—he alone attains real peace.
verses.transliteration: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṁś carati niḥspṛhaḥ nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchati
verses.meaning: This verse emphasizes that one who abandons desires, is selfless, and is free from ego attains true peace.

verses.sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति । स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति ॥ ७२ ॥
verses.translation: That is the way of the spiritual life, after attaining which a man is not bewildered. Being so established, even at the hour of death, one attains to the supreme abode of God.
verses.transliteration: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṁ prāpya vimuhyati sthitvāsyām-antakāle 'pi brahma-nirvāṇam ṛcchati
verses.meaning: This verse concludes the chapter by describing the state of spiritual enlightenment and liberation that one can attain, even at the time of death, by being established in this consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच । ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन । तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव ॥ १ ॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Janardana, if intelligence is considered by You to be better than fruitive action, why do You engage me in this terrible warfare?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana tat kiṁ karmaṇi ghore māṁ niyojayasi keśava
verses.meaning: Arjuna questions Krishna about the necessity of action if knowledge is superior.

verses.sanskrit: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे । तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् ॥ २ ॥
verses.translation: My intelligence is bewildered by Your equivocal instructions. Therefore, please tell me decisively which path is most beneficial for me.
verses.transliteration: vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṁ mohayasīva me tad ekaṁ vada niścitya yena śreyo 'ham āpnuyām
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his confusion and asks for a clear path to follow.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच । लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ । ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् ॥ ३ ॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: O sinless Arjuna, I have already explained that there are two classes of men who try to realize the self. Some are inclined to work with fruitive results, while others are inclined to knowledge of the Absolute.
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayānagha jñāna-yogena sāṅkhyānāṁ karma-yogena yoginām
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the two paths: the path of knowledge and the path of action.

verses.sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते । न च सन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति ॥ ४ ॥
verses.translation: Not by merely abstaining from work can one achieve freedom from reaction, nor by renunciation alone can one attain perfection.
verses.transliteration: na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣkarmyaṁ puruṣo 'śnute na ca sannyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna clarifies that neither inaction nor mere renunciation leads to perfection.

verses.sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् । कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः ॥ ५ ॥
verses.translation: Everyone is forced to act helplessly according to the qualities he has acquired from the modes of material nature; therefore no one can refrain from doing something, not even for a moment.
verses.transliteration: na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarma-kṛt kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that action is unavoidable as everyone is influenced by the modes of nature.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् । इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते ॥ ६ ॥
verses.translation: One who restrains the senses of action but whose mind dwells on sense objects certainly deludes himself and is called a pretender.
verses.transliteration: karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya ya āste manasā smaran indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna warns against the hypocrisy of outwardly restraining actions while the mind is still attached to sense objects.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन । कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते ॥ ७ ॥
verses.translation: But one who with his mind controls the active senses and engages his organs of action in work without attachment is superior.
verses.transliteration: yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamya ārabhate 'rjuna karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the importance of performing one's duty without attachment.

verses.sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः । शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः ॥ ८ ॥
verses.translation: Perform your prescribed duty, for action is better than inaction. A man cannot even maintain his physical body without work.
verses.transliteration: niyataṁ kuru karma tvaṁ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ śarīra-yātrāpi ca te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna stresses the necessity of performing one's duties, even for the maintenance of the body.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः । तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर ॥ ९ ॥
verses.translation: Work done as a sacrifice for Vishnu has to be performed; otherwise work binds one to this material world. Therefore, O son of Kunti, perform your prescribed duties for His satisfaction, and in that way you will always remain unattached and free from bondage.
verses.transliteration: yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ tad-arthaṁ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samācara
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that work done as a sacrifice for Vishnu does not lead to bondage.

verses.sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः । अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् ॥ १० ॥
verses.translation: In the beginning of creation, the Lord of creatures sent forth generations of men and demigods, along with sacrifices for Vishnu, and said, "Be thou happy by this sacrifice and let this sacrifice be the fulfiller of all your desires."
verses.transliteration: saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purovāca prajāpatiḥ anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vo 'stv iṣṭa-kāma-dhuk
verses.meaning: The importance of sacrifice is highlighted as a means to attain desired ends.

verses.sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः । परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ ॥ ११ ॥
verses.translation: The demigods, being pleased by sacrifices, will also please you; and thus, by cooperation between men and demigods, prosperity will reign for all.
verses.transliteration: devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ parasparaṁ bhāvayantaḥ śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha
verses.meaning: The benefits of mutual cooperation between humans and demigods through sacrifice are described.

verses.sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः । तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः ॥ १२ ॥
verses.translation: In charge of the various necessities of life, the demigods, being satisfied by the performance of sacrifice, will supply all your needs. But he who enjoys the gifts supplied by them without offering them in return is certainly a thief.
verses.transliteration: iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajña-bhāvitāḥ tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
verses.meaning: The necessity of offering in return for what is received is emphasized.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः । भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् ॥ १३ ॥
verses.translation: The devotees of the Lord are released from all kinds of sins because they eat food which is offered first for sacrifice. Others, who prepare food for personal sense enjoyment, verily eat only sin.
verses.transliteration: yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarva-kilbiṣaiḥ bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt
verses.meaning: The importance of eating food offered as sacrifice is highlighted.

verses.sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः । यज्ञात्कर्मसमुद्भवः ॥ १४ ॥
verses.translation: All living bodies subsist on foodgrains, which are produced from rains. Rains are produced by performance of sacrifice, and sacrifice is born of prescribed duties.
verses.transliteration: annād bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyād anna-sambhavaḥ yajñāt karma-samudbhavaḥ
verses.meaning: The cycle of interdependence between food, rain, sacrifice, and prescribed duties is explained.

verses.sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् । तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् ॥ १५ ॥
verses.translation: Regulated activities are prescribed in the Vedas, and the Vedas are directly manifested from the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Consequently the all-pervading Transcendence is eternally situated in acts of sacrifice.
verses.transliteration: karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣara-samudbhavam tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
verses.meaning: The divine origin of prescribed duties and their connection to sacrifice is established.

verses.sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः । अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति ॥ १६ ॥
verses.translation: My dear Arjuna, one who does not follow in human life the cycle of sacrifice thus set in motion by the Vedas certainly leads a sinful life. Living only for the satisfaction of the senses, such a person lives in vain.
verses.transliteration: evaṁ pravartitaṁ cakraṁ nānuvartayatīha yaḥ aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati
verses.meaning: The consequences of not following the cycle of sacrifice and living only for sense gratification are described.

verses.sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः । आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते ॥ १७ ॥
verses.translation: But for one who takes pleasure in the Self, whose human life is one of self-realization, and who is satisfied in the Self only, there is no duty.
verses.transliteration: yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ ātmany eva ca santuṣṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate
verses.meaning: The state of self-realization, where there is no obligatory duty, is described.

verses.sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृत्ये नैकृत्ये नार्थोऽस्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदव्यपाश्रयः ॥ १८ ॥
verses.translation: A self-realized man has no purpose to fulfill in the discharge of his prescribed duties, nor has he any reason not to perform such work. Nor has he any need to depend on any other living being.
verses.transliteration: naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛteneha kaścana nārthaś cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu kaścid vyapāśrayaḥ
verses.meaning: The actions of a self-realized person are explained.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर । असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः ॥ १९ ॥
verses.translation: Therefore, without being attached to the fruits of activity, one should act as a matter of duty, for by working without attachment one attains the supreme goal.
verses.transliteration: tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samācara asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ
verses.meaning: The importance of performing one's duty without attachment to the results is reiterated.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः । लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि ॥ २० ॥
verses.translation: Kings such as Janaka attained perfection solely by performance of prescribed duties. Therefore, just for the sake of educating the people in general, you should perform your work.
verses.transliteration: karmaṇaiva hi saṁsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśyan kartum arhasi
verses.meaning: The example of King Janaka is given to emphasize the importance of performing one's duties.

verses.sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः । स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते ॥ २१ ॥
verses.translation: Whatever action a great man performs, common men follow. And whatever standards he sets by his exemplary acts, all the world pursues.
verses.transliteration: yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate
verses.meaning: The influence of a great man's actions on the common people is explained.

verses.sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किंचन । नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि ॥ २२ ॥
verses.translation: O son of Pritha, there is no work prescribed for Me within all the three worlds—nothing to be gained and nothing to be acquired—and yet I am engaged in work.
verses.transliteration: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣu lokeṣu kiṁcana nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva ca karmaṇi
verses.meaning: Krishna, despite being free from obligations, continues to work.

verses.sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः । मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥ २३ ॥
verses.translation: For if I did not engage in work, O Partha, all men would certainly follow My path in every respect.
verses.transliteration: yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
verses.meaning: The consequences of Krishna not working are described.

verses.sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम् । सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः ॥ २४ ॥
verses.translation: If I did not perform prescribed duties, all these worlds would be put to ruination. I would be the cause of creating unwanted population, and I would thereby destroy the peace of all living beings.
verses.transliteration: utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ced aham saṅkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains how His inaction would lead to chaos and destruction.

verses.sanskrit: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत । कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम् ॥ २५ ॥
verses.translation: As the ignorant perform their duties with attachment to results, similarly the learned may also act, but without attachment, for the sake of leading people to the right path.
verses.transliteration: saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṁso yathā kurvanti bhārata kuryād vidvāṁs tathāsaktaś cikīrṣur loka-saṅgraham
verses.meaning: The difference between how the ignorant and the learned perform their duties is explained.

verses.sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् । जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्तः समाचरन् ॥ २६ ॥
verses.translation: So as not to disturb the minds of ignorant men attached to the fruits of action, a learned person should not indulge in inaction; rather, by working in the spirit of devotion, he should set them an example.
verses.transliteration: na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām joṣayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācaran
