verses.meaning: The responsibility of the learned to guide the ignorant through action is emphasized.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः । अहंकारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते ॥ २७ ॥
verses.translation: The bewildered spirit soul, under the influence of the three modes of material nature, thinks himself to be the doer of activities that are in actuality carried out by nature.
verses.transliteration: prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate
verses.meaning: The illusion of the ego in considering oneself as the doer is explained.

verses.sanskrit: तत्त्ववित् तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः । गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते ॥ २८ ॥
verses.translation: One who is in knowledge of the Absolute Truth, O mighty-armed Arjuna, does not engage himself in the senses and sense gratification, knowing well the distinctions between the elements of his material body and the pure soul.
verses.transliteration: tattvavit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ guṇā guṇeṣu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate
verses.meaning: The perspective of one who knows the Absolute Truth regarding actions and their consequences is described.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु । तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् ॥ २९ ॥
verses.translation: Bewildered by the modes of material nature, the ignorant fully engage themselves in material activities and become attached. But the wise should not disturb them, though these actions are less important because the ignorant have no knowledge of the Supreme.
verses.transliteration: prakṛter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu tān akṛtsna-vido mandān kṛtsnavin na vicālayet
verses.meaning: The wise should not disturb the ignorant who are attached to material activities.

verses.sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि सन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा । निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥ ३० ॥
verses.translation: O Arjuna, surrendering all your works unto Me, with full knowledge of Me, without desires for profit, with no claims to proprietorship, and free from lethargy, fight.
verses.transliteration: mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-cetasā nirāśīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to fight without attachment, dedicating all actions to Him.

verses.sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः । श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः ॥ ३१ ॥
verses.translation: Those who perform their duties according to My injunctions and who follow this teaching faithfully, without envy, become free from the bondage of fruitive actions.
verses.transliteration: ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ śraddhāvanto 'nasūyanto mucyante te 'pi karmabhiḥ
verses.meaning: The path to liberation through following Krishna's teachings with faith and without envy is described.

verses.sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् । सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः ॥ ३२ ॥
verses.translation: But those who, out of envy, disregard these teachings and do not follow them are to be considered bereft of all knowledge, bewildered, and doomed to ruin.
verses.transliteration: ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāṁs tān viddhi naṣṭān acetasaḥ
verses.meaning: The consequences of disregarding Krishna's teachings are explained.

verses.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि । प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति ॥ ३३ ॥
verses.translation: Even a man of knowledge acts according to his own nature, for everyone follows the nature he has acquired from the three modes. What can repression accomplish?
verses.transliteration: sadṛśaṁ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛter jñānavān api prakṛtiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣyati
verses.meaning: The influence of one's nature on their actions is highlighted.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ । तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ ॥ ३४ ॥
verses.translation: There are principles to regulate attachment and aversion pertaining to the senses and sense objects. One should not come under their control, because they are obstacles on the path of self-realization.
verses.transliteration: indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣau vyavasthitau tayor na vaśam āgacchet tau hy asya paripanthinau
verses.meaning: The obstacles of attachment and aversion in the path of self-realization are described.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् । स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः ॥ ३५ ॥
verses.translation: It is far better to discharge one's prescribed duties, even though faultily, than to perform another's duties perfectly. Destruction in the course of performing one's own duty is better than engaging in the duties of another, for following another's path is always dangerous.
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt svanuṣṭhitāt sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ
verses.meaning: The importance of performing one's own duty, even if imperfectly, is emphasized.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
verses.translation: It is far better to perform one's natural prescribed duty, though tinged with faults, than to perform another's prescribed duty, though perfectly. One should perform his duties according to his own nature; one who tries to follow another's nature will be destroyed.
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ para-dharmo bhaya-āvahaḥ
verses.meaning: This verse emphasizes the importance of fulfilling one's own duties (sva-dharma) even if imperfectly, rather than attempting to perform the duties of others (para-dharma). It asserts that adhering to one's own path, even if it leads to death, is preferable to following another's path, which is fraught with danger.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पुरुषः। अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: But driven by what, O Krishna, does man commit sin, even against his will, as if by force?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca atha kena prayukto'yaṁ pāpaṁ carati puruṣaḥ anicchann api vārṣṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna inquires about the cause that compels individuals to act sinfully, even against their own will, as if driven by an external force.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्धयेनमिह वैरिणम्॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: It is lust, it is anger, born of the mode of passion; this is the all-devouring, all-sinful enemy of man.
verses.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ mahā-śano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that lust and anger, arising from the mode of passion, are the great enemies that drive men to sinful actions.

verses.sanskrit: धूमenevāव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्येनाऽवृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्॥
verses.translation: As fire is covered by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, or as the embryo is covered by the womb, so this knowledge is covered by different degrees of this lust.
verses.transliteration: dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśo malena ca yatholbenāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam
verses.meaning: Krishna uses analogies to illustrate how lust obscures knowledge, comparing it to smoke covering fire, dust covering a mirror, and the womb covering an embryo.

verses.sanskrit: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च॥
verses.translation: Thus the wise living entity's pure consciousness is covered by his eternal enemy, which is lust, which is never satisfied and burns like fire.
verses.transliteration: āvṛtaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca
verses.meaning: Krishna further emphasizes that this insatiable lust is the eternal enemy of the wise, constantly obscuring their true knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्॥
verses.translation: The senses, the mind and the intelligence are the sitting places for this lust. Through them lust covers the real knowledge of the living entity and bewilders him.
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate etair vimohayaty eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam
verses.meaning: Krishna identifies the senses, mind, and intelligence as the places where lust resides, through which it deludes and covers the knowledge of the embodied soul.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्॥
verses.translation: Therefore, O Arjuna, best of the Bharatas, in the very beginning curb this lust by regulating the senses, and slay this destroyer of knowledge and self-realization.
verses.transliteration: tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣabha pāpmānaṁ prajahy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to control the senses from the outset in order to destroy this lust, which is the enemy of knowledge and self-realization.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः। मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः॥
verses.translation: The working senses are superior to dull matter; mind is higher than the senses; intelligence is still higher than the mind; and he [the soul] is even higher than the intelligence.
verses.transliteration: indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ manasas tu parā buddhir buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the hierarchy of sensory experience, mind, intelligence, and the soul, emphasizing that the soul is supreme.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना। जहि शत्रुं महाबाहु कामरूपं दुरासदम्॥
verses.translation: Thus knowing oneself to be transcendental to the material senses, mind and intelligence, O mighty-armed Arjuna, one should steady the mind by deliberate spiritual intelligence [Kṛṣṇa consciousness] and thus conquer this insatiable enemy known as lust.
verses.transliteration: evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā jahi śatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by urging Arjuna to use his intelligence to control his mind, recognize his transcendental nature, and conquer the formidable enemy of lust.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: I instructed this imperishable science of yoga to the sun-god, Vivasvan, and Vivasvan instructed it to Manu, and Manu in turn spoke it to King Ikshvaku.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave 'bravīt
verses.meaning: Krishna begins by explaining the lineage of the knowledge of yoga, tracing it back to the sun-god, Vivasvan.

verses.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप॥
verses.translation: This supreme science was thus received through the chain of disciplic succession, and the saintly kings understood it in that way. But in course of time the succession was broken, and therefore the science as it is appears to be lost.
verses.transliteration: evaṁ paramparā-prāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ paran-tapa
verses.meaning: Krishna continues to describe how the knowledge was passed down through a succession of saintly kings, but was eventually lost over time.

verses.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्॥
verses.translation: That very ancient science of the relationship with the Supreme I am today telling to you because you are both My devotee and My friend; therefore you can understand this transcendental mystery.
verses.transliteration: sa evāyaṁ mayā te 'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ bhakto 'si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam
verses.meaning: Krishna reveals to Arjuna that he is re-imparting this ancient knowledge of yoga to him because Arjuna is his devotee and friend.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: The sun-god Vivasvan is senior by birth to You. How am I to understand that in the beginning You instructed this science to him?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his confusion about how Krishna could have taught this knowledge to Vivasvan, who was born much earlier.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Many, many births both you and I have passed through. I know all of them, but you do not know, O subduer of the enemy!
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna tāny ahaṁ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṁ vettha paran-tapa
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that both he and Arjuna have had many births, but he remembers them all, while Arjuna does not.

verses.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया॥
verses.translation: Although I am unborn, and My transcendental body never deteriorates, and although I am the Lord of all living entities, I still appear in every millennium in My original transcendental form.
verses.transliteration: ajo 'pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro 'pi san prakṛtiṁ svām adhiṣṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā
verses.meaning: Krishna reveals his divine nature, explaining that he appears in every age in his transcendental form, even though he is unborn and eternal.

verses.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
verses.translation: Whenever and wherever there is a decline in righteousness and an increase in unrighteousness, at that time I descend Myself.
verses.transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata abhyutthānam adharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham
verses.meaning: Krishna speaks about his role in restoring dharma (righteousness) whenever it declines.

verses.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
verses.translation: To deliver the pious and to annihilate the miscreants, as well as to reestablish the principles of religion, I Myself appear, millennium after millennium.
verses.transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge
verses.meaning: Krishna elaborates on the purpose of his incarnations: to protect the righteous, destroy the wicked, and re-establish dharma.

verses.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन॥
verses.translation: One who knows the transcendental nature of My appearance and activities does not, upon leaving the body, take his birth again in this material world, but attains My eternal abode, O Arjuna.
verses.transliteration: janma karma ca me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so 'rjuna
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that understanding the transcendental nature of his birth and activities leads to liberation.

verses.sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः। बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः॥
verses.translation: Being freed from attachment, fear and anger, and being fully absorbed in Me and taking refuge in Me, many, many persons have already attained perfection in the past. Thus they all attained transcendental love for Me.
verses.transliteration: vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes how many people in the past have attained perfection and transcendental love for him by becoming freed from attachment, fear, and anger, and by taking refuge in him.

verses.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
verses.translation: As all surrender unto Me, I reward them accordingly. Everyone follows My path in all respects, O son of Pṛthā.
verses.transliteration: ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that he reciprocates with his devotees according to their surrender and that everyone follows his path in some way.

verses.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा॥
verses.translation: Men in this world desire success in fruitive activities, and therefore they worship the demigods. Quickly, of course, men get results from pious work in this world.
verses.transliteration: kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajanta iha devatāḥ kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karma-jā
verses.meaning: Krishna notes that those seeking quick results from their actions often worship demigods.

verses.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्॥
verses.translation: According to the three modes of material nature and the work ascribed to them, the four divisions of human society were created by Me. And, although I am the creator of this system, you should know that I am yet the non-doer, being inalienable.
verses.transliteration: cātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhy akartāram avyayam
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the origin of the four divisions of human society (varna) based on the modes of material nature and their corresponding work. He also clarifies that although he is the creator, he remains unaffected and is the non-doer.

verses.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते॥
verses.translation: There is no work that affects Me; nor do I aspire for any fruit of action. One who understands this truth about Me also does not become entangled in the reaction of works.
verses.transliteration: na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me phale spṛhā iti māṁ yo 'bhijānāti karmabhir na sa badhyate
verses.meaning: Krishna asserts that actions do not affect him, nor does he desire the fruits of action. Understanding this, one is not bound by karma.

verses.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्॥
verses.translation: All the liberated souls in ancient times acted with this understanding of My transcendental nature. Therefore you should perform your duty, following in their footsteps.
verses.transliteration: evaṁ jñātvā kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ kuru karmaiva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam
verses.meaning: Krishna encourages Arjuna to perform his duty, following the example of liberated souls from the past who acted with this understanding.

verses.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्॥
verses.translation: Even the wise are confused in determining what is action and what is inaction. Now I shall explain to you what action is, knowing which you shall be freed from all misfortune.
verses.transliteration: kiṁ karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitāḥ tat te karma pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt
verses.meaning: Krishna acknowledges that even the wise are perplexed about the nature of action and inaction. He promises to explain this to Arjuna, so he can be liberated from misfortune.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः॥
verses.translation: The intricacies of action are very hard to understand. Therefore one should know properly what action is, what forbidden action is, and what inaction is.
verses.transliteration: karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ ca vikarmanaḥ akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the complexity of understanding action, forbidden action, and inaction, stating that the path of action is intricate.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्॥
verses.translation: One who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is intelligent among men, and he is in the transcendental position, engaged in performing all kinds of activities.
verses.transliteration: karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the enlightened perspective of seeing inaction in action and vice versa, identifying such a person as truly intelligent and a performer of all actions in a transcendental state.

verses.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः॥
verses.translation: One is understood to be in full knowledge whose every endeavor is devoid of desire for sense gratification. He is said by sages to be a worker for whom the reactions of work have been burned up by the fire of perfect knowledge.
verses.transliteration: yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a person of perfect knowledge as one whose actions are devoid of desire for sense gratification and whose karma is burned up by the fire of knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः॥
verses.translation: He who has given up all attachment to the results of his activities is ever satisfied and independent; he performs no fruitive action, although engaged in all kinds of undertakings.
verses.transliteration: tyaktvā karma-phalāsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ karmaṇy abhipravṛtto 'pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the state of a liberated person who has renounced attachment to the results of actions and is always satisfied and independent. Even while acting, he performs no fruitive action.

verses.sanskrit: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः। शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥
verses.translation: Such a man of understanding acts with mind and intelligence perfectly controlled, gives up all sense of proprietary ownership over his possessions and acts only for the bare necessities of life. Thus working, he is not affected by sinful reactions.
verses.transliteration: nirāśīr yata-cittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ śārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes a person who acts with controlled mind and intelligence, gives up ownership, and works only for basic needs, remaining unaffected by sinful reactions.

verses.sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः। समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते॥
verses.translation: One who is satisfied with gain which comes of its own accord, who is free from duality and does not envy, who is steady both in success and failure, is never entangled, although performing actions.
verses.transliteration: yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ samaḥ siddhāv asiddhau ca kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes someone who is content with what comes naturally, is free from dualities and envy, and remainsEquanimous in success and failure. Such a person, though performing actions, is never entangled by them.

verses.sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः। यज्ञाय चरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते॥
verses.translation: The work of a man who is unattached to the modes of material nature and who is fully situated in transcendental knowledge merges entirely into transcendence.
verses.transliteration: gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ yajñāya carataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that the actions of a liberated person, who is unattached and fully situated in transcendental knowledge, merge entirely into transcendence.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना॥
verses.translation: For one who is fully absorbed in Kṛṣṇa consciousness, everything offered in sacrifice is Brahman; the act of consumption is Brahman; the performer is Brahman; and the result is also Brahman.
verses.transliteration: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the perspective of a person fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness, where everything is seen as Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति॥
verses.translation: Some yogīs perfectly worship the demigods with sacrifices, and some offer sacrifices in the fire of the Supreme Brahman.
verses.transliteration: daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes different types of sacrifices performed by yogis: some worship demigods, while others sacrifice into the fire of the Supreme Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति। शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति॥
verses.translation: Some [the unadulterated brahmacārīs] sacrifice the hearing process and the senses in the fire of mental control, and others [the regulated householders] sacrifice the sense objects, such as sound, in the fire of the senses.
verses.transliteration: śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṁyamāgniṣu juhvati śabdādīn viṣayān anya indriyāgniṣu juhvati
verses.meaning: Krishna continues to describe various types of sacrifices, including those where senses are offered into the fire of self-control, and sense objects into the fire of the senses.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे। आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते॥
verses.translation: Others, who are interested in self-realization through control of the mind and senses, offer the functions of all the senses and life breath as oblations into the fire of the controlled mind.
verses.transliteration: sarvāṇīndriya-karmāṇi prāṇa-karmāṇi cāpare ātma-saṁyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñāna-dīpite
verses.meaning: Krishna describes those who sacrifice the functions of their senses and life breath into the fire of the controlled mind, fueled by knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे। स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः॥
verses.translation: Some are sacrificing their material possessions, some are undergoing severe austerities, some are practicing the yoga system, and some are engaged in the study of Vedic literature to advance in transcendental knowledge.
verses.transliteration: dravya-yajñās tapo-yajñā yoga-yajñās tathāpare svādhyāya-jñāna-yajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṁśita-vratāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna outlines different types of sacrifices: sacrificing material possessions, undergoing austerities, practicing yoga, and studying Vedic literature.

verses.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणंप्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः॥
verses.translation: Still others, who are inclined to the process of breath control, stop the movement of the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming breath into the outgoing, and thus remain in that state, stopping all kinds of breath movement. Others, reducing the eating process, offer the very life breath into itself as a sacrifice.
verses.transliteration: apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe 'pānaṁ tathāpare prāṇāpāna-gatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the practice of breath control (pranayama) and the regulation of eating as forms of sacrifice.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः। यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्॥
verses.translation: All these performers who know the meaning of sacrifice become cleansed of sinful reactions, and, having tasted the nectar of the results of sacrifices, they advance toward the supreme eternal abode.
verses.transliteration: sarve 'py ete yajña-vido yajña-kṣapita-kalmaṣāḥ yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that those who understand the meaning of sacrifice are purified of sins and attain the supreme eternal abode by partaking in the results of their sacrifices.

verses.sanskrit: नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम॥
verses.translation: O best of the Kurus, without sacrifice one can never be happy on this planet or in this life; what to speak of the next?
verses.transliteration: nāyaṁ loko 'sty ayajñasya kuto 'nyaḥ kurusattama
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the importance of sacrifice, stating that without it, one cannot be happy in this life or the next.

verses.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि सर्वানেवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे॥
verses.translation: All these different kinds of sacrifice are approved by the Vedas, and all of them are born of varied activities. Knowing them as such, you will become liberated.
verses.transliteration: evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe karma-jān viddhi sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimo kṣyase
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that these various sacrifices are sanctioned by the Vedas and arise from different kinds of work. Understanding this leads to liberation.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते॥
verses.translation: O chastiser of the enemy, the sacrifice performed in knowledge is greater than the mere sacrifice of material possessions. O son of Pṛthā, after all, the result of all activities is to be found in knowledge.
verses.transliteration: śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ paran-tapa sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate
verses.meaning: Krishna declares that the sacrifice performed in knowledge is superior to material sacrifices, as all actions ultimately culminate in knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
verses.translation: Just try to learn the truth by approaching a spiritual master. Inquire from him submissively and render service unto him. The self-realized souls can impart knowledge unto you because they have seen the truth.
verses.transliteration: tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to seek knowledge from a self-realized spiritual master by approaching him with humility, sincere inquiry, and service.

verses.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषणि द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि॥
verses.translation: And when you have thus learned the truth, you will know that all living beings are but parts of Me—and that they are in Me. Then your mind will be fixed on Me.
verses.transliteration: yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava yena bhūtāny aśeṣāṇi drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that by gaining this knowledge, Arjuna will overcome delusion and see all beings as parts of him and residing in him.

verses.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि॥
verses.translation: Even if you are considered the most sinful of all sinners, when you are situated in the boat of transcendental knowledge, you will be able to cross over the ocean of miseries.
verses.transliteration: api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛttamaḥ sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna assures Arjuna that even the greatest sinner can cross the ocean of suffering by being situated in the boat of transcendental knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा॥
verses.translation: As a blazing fire turns firewood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge burn to ashes all reactions to material activities.
verses.transliteration: yathaidhāṁsi samiddho 'gnir bhasmasāt kurute 'rjuna jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā
verses.meaning: Krishna compares the fire of knowledge to a blazing fire that turns firewood to ashes, stating that it similarly destroys all reactions to material activities.

verses.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति॥
verses.translation: In this world, there is nothing so sublime and pure as transcendental knowledge. Such knowledge is the mature fruit of all mystic aspirations. And one who has become accomplished in the practice of devotional service enjoys this knowledge within himself in due course of time.
verses.transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the unparalleled purity and sublimity of transcendental knowledge, which is attained by one accomplished in devotional service over time.

verses.sanskrit: श्रद्धावानल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
verses.translation: A faithful man who is dedicated to transcendental knowledge and who subdues his senses is eligible to achieve such knowledge, and having achieved it, he quickly attains the supreme spiritual peace.
verses.transliteration: śraddhāvān labhate jñānaṁ tat-paraḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim acireṇādhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of a person eligible for transcendental knowledge: faith, dedication, and sense control. Such a person attains supreme peace.

verses.sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति। नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः॥
verses.translation: But ignorant and faithless persons who doubt the revealed scriptures do not attain God consciousness; they fall down. For the doubting soul there is neither this world nor the next, nor happiness.
verses.transliteration: ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati nāyaṁ loko 'sti na paro na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna warns against ignorance, faithlessness, and doubt, stating that they lead to downfall and the absence of happiness in this world and the next.

verses.sanskrit: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम्। आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनंजय॥
verses.translation: O conqueror of riches, one who works in devotional service, renouncing the fruits of his actions, whose doubts are destroyed by transcendental knowledge, is situated perfectly. He is therefore not bound by actions.
verses.transliteration: yoga-saṁnyasta-karmāṇaṁ jñāna-saṁchinna-saṁśayam ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the liberated state of one who works in devotional service, has renounced the fruits of action, and whose doubts are destroyed by knowledge. Such a person is not bound by karma.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसंभूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः। छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत॥
verses.translation: Therefore the doubts which have arisen in your heart out of ignorance should be slashed by the weapon of knowledge. Armed with yoga, O Bhārata, stand and fight.
verses.transliteration: tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinātmanaḥ chittvainaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam ātiṣṭhottiṣṭha bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by urging Arjuna to dispel his doubts with the weapon of knowledge and to take up the path of yoga and fight.

chapters.chapter_name: Karma Yoga - Action in Krishna Consciousness

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि। यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम्॥
verses.translation: Arjuna asked: O Krishna, first You ask me to renounce work, and then again You recommend work with devotion. Now will You kindly tell me definitely which of the two is more beneficial?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca sannyāsaṁ karmaṇāṁ kṛṣṇa punar yogaṁ ca śaṁsasi yac chreya etayor ekaṁ tan me brūhi suniścitam
verses.meaning: Arjuna seeks clarification from Krishna about whether renunciation of action or action with devotion is more beneficial.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ। तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: The renunciation of work and work in devotion are both good for liberation. But, of the two, work in devotional service is better than renunciation of work.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca sannyāsaḥ karma-yogaś ca niḥśreyasa-karāv ubhau tayos tu karma-sannyāsāt karma-yogo viśiṣyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that both renunciation and devotional service lead to liberation, but devotional service is superior.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति। निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते॥
verses.translation: One who neither hates nor desires the fruits of his activities is always situated in the renounced order of life. Such a person easily overcomes material bondage and is completely liberated, O mighty-armed Arjuna.
verses.transliteration: jñeyaḥ sa nitya-sannyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho sukhaṁ bandhāt pramucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a true renunciant as one who is free from hatred and desire and who transcends duality, thus achieving liberation.

verses.sanskrit: साङ्ख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः। एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम्॥
verses.translation: Only the ignorant speak of the path of devotional service [karma-yoga] as being different from the process of speculation [Sankhya]. Those who are truly learned say that he who applies himself well to one of these paths achieves the results of both.
verses.transliteration: sāṅkhya-yogau pṛthag bālāḥ pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag ubhayor vindate phalam
verses.meaning: Krishna clarifies that karma-yoga and Sankhya are not truly different paths, and that sincere practice of either leads to the same result.

verses.sanskrit: यत्साङ्ख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते। एकं साङ्ख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति॥
verses.translation: One who knows that the position reached by means of analytical study can also be attained by devotional service, and who therefore sees analytical study and devotional work to be on the same level, sees things as they are.
verses.transliteration: yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṁ tad yogair api gamyate ekaṁ sāṅkhyaṁ ca yogaṁ ca yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
verses.meaning: Krishna reiterates the unity of the paths of knowledge and action, stating that they lead to the same goal and that one who understands this sees the truth.

verses.sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः। योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
verses.translation: Merely to renounce all activities yet not to engage in the devotional service of the Lord cannot make one happy. But a thoughtful person engaged in devotional service can achieve the Supreme without delay.
verses.transliteration: sannyāsas tu mahā-bāho duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ yoga-yukto munir brahma na cireṇādhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes that renunciation without devotion is difficult and does not lead to happiness, while devotion leads to the Supreme quickly.

verses.sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः। सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते॥
verses.translation: One who works in devotion with a pure soul, who controls his mind and senses, is dear to everyone, and everyone is dear to him. Though always working, such a man is never entangled.
verses.transliteration: yoga-yukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā kurvann api na lipyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of a person engaged in devotional service: purity, self-control, and universal compassion. Such a person is not bound by his actions.

verses.sanskrit: नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्। पश्यञ् शृण्वन् स्पृशञ् जिघ्रन्नश्नन् गच्छन् स्वपन् श्वसन्॥
verses.translation: A person in the divine consciousness, although engaged in seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving about, sleeping and breathing, always knows within himself that he is doing nothing at all. Because while speaking, evacuating, receiving or holding, or even opening or closing his eyes, he always knows that only the material senses are engaged with their objects and that he is aloof from them.
verses.transliteration: naiva kiñcit karomīti yukto manyeta tattva-vit paśyañ śṛṇvan spṛśaň jighrann aśnan gacchan svapan śvasan
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the consciousness of a person who understands the true nature of action, recognizing that the senses operate independently and the self is aloof.

verses.sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन् गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन्॥
verses.translation: (same as previous verse)
verses.transliteration: pralapan visṛjan gṛhṇann unmiṣan nimiṣann api indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu vartanta iti dhārayan
verses.meaning: (Same as previous verse) This verse continues to elaborate on the actions of the senses, reinforcing the understanding of detachment.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः। लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा॥
verses.translation: One who performs his duty without attachment, surrendering the results unto the Supreme Lord, is unaffected by sinful action, as the lotus leaf is untouched by water.
verses.transliteration: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ lipyate na sa pāpena padma-patram ivāmbhasā
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that performing actions without attachment and surrendering the results to the Lord keeps one from being tainted by sin, like a lotus leaf in water.

verses.sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि। योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मशुद्धये॥
verses.translation: The yogīs, abandoning attachment, act with body, mind, intelligence and even with the senses, only for the purpose of purification.
verses.transliteration: kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyair api yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṁ tyaktvā''tma-śuddhaye
verses.meaning: Krishna says that yogis perform actions with their body, mind, intelligence, and senses, without attachment, solely for self-purification.

verses.sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्। अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते॥
verses.translation: The steadily devoted soul attains unadulterated peace because he offers the result of all activities to Me; whereas the person who is not in union with the Divine, who is greedy for the fruits of his labor, becomes entangled.
verses.transliteration: yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā śāntim āpnoti naiṣṭhikīm ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate
verses.meaning: Krishna contrasts the person who dedicates the fruits of their actions and attains peace with the one attached to the results, who becomes entangled.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा सन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी। नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन्॥
verses.translation: When the embodied living being controls his nature and mentally renounces all actions, he resides happily in the city of nine gates [the material body], neither working nor causing work to be done.
verses.transliteration: sarva-karmāṇi manasā sanyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśī nava-dvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan
verses.meaning: Krishna describes how the embodied being, by controlling their nature and mentally renouncing actions, dwells contentedly, neither acting nor causing action.

verses.sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः। न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते॥
verses.translation: The embodied spirit, master of the city of his body, does not create activities, nor does he induce people to act, nor does he create the fruits of action. All this is enacted by the modes of material nature.
verses.transliteration: na kartṛtvaṁ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ na karma-phala-saṁyogaṁ svabhāvas tu pravartate
verses.meaning: Krishna clarifies that the soul does not create action, the motivation to act, or the results of action; these are all influenced by the modes of material nature.

verses.sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः। अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः॥
verses.translation: Nor does the Supreme Lord assume anyone's sinful or pious activities. Embodied beings, however, are bewildered because of ignorance, which covers their real knowledge.
verses.transliteration: nādatte kasyacit pāpaṁ na caiva sukṛtaṁ vibhuḥ ajñānenāvṛtaṁ jñānaṁ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna affirms that the Lord does not take on anyone's good or bad deeds; living beings are deluded by ignorance that obscures their true knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः। तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम्॥
verses.translation: When, however, one is enlightened by the knowledge by which ignorance is destroyed, then his knowledge reveals everything, as the sun lights up everything during the day.
verses.transliteration: jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ yeṣāṁ nāśitam ātmanaḥ teṣām ādityavat jñānaṁ prakāśayati tat param
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that when ignorance is destroyed by knowledge, that knowledge illuminates everything, just as the sun reveals everything in daylight.

verses.sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः। गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः॥
verses.translation: When one's intelligence, mind, faith and refuge are all fixed in the Supreme, then one becomes fully cleansed of misgivings through complete knowledge and thus proceeds straight to the path of liberation.
verses.transliteration: tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānas tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ gacchanty apunar-āvṛttiṁ jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes how those whose intelligence, mind, faith, and refuge are in the Supreme attain liberation, their impurities washed away by knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि। शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः॥
verses.translation: The humble sages, by virtue of true knowledge, see with equal vision a learned and gentle brāhmaṇa, a cow, an elephant, a dog and a dog-eater [outcaste].
verses.transliteration: vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini śuni caiva śva-pāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna states that true sages, with their knowledge, see all beings with equanimity, regardless of their social standing or species.

verses.sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः। निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद् ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः॥
verses.translation: Those whose minds are established in sameness and equanimity have already conquered the conditions of birth and death. They are flawless like Brahman, and they are already situated in Brahman.
verses.transliteration: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ nirdoṣaṁ hi samaṁ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that those who maintain equanimity have already overcome birth and death and are situated in Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्। स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद् ब्रह्मणि स्थितः॥
verses.translation: A person who neither rejoices upon achieving something pleasant nor laments upon obtaining something unpleasant, who is self-intelligent, who is unbewildered, and who knows the science of God, is already situated in transcendence.
verses.transliteration: na prahṛṣyet priyaṁ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam sthira-buddhir asammūḍho brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a person established in transcendence as one who is unmoved by pleasant or unpleasant events, is self-intelligent, and knows the science of God.

verses.sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्। स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते॥
verses.translation: Such a liberated person is not attracted to material sense enjoyment but is always in meditation, enjoying the pleasure within. In this way the self-realized person constantly engages in uninterrupted spiritual life.
verses.transliteration: bāhya-sparśeṣv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute
verses.meaning: Krishna says that a liberated person finds pleasure within through meditation and engages in uninterrupted spiritual life, detached from external sense pleasures.

verses.sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते। आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः॥
verses.translation: An intelligent person does not take part in the sources of misery, which are due to contact with the material senses. O son of Kunti, such pleasures have a beginning and an end, and so the wise derive no pleasure from them.
verses.transliteration: ye hi saṁsparśa-jā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te ādy-antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that sense pleasures are the source of misery, as they are temporary and have a beginning and an end; therefore, the wise do not enjoy them.

verses.sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्। कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः॥
verses.translation: If one is able to tolerate the disturbance of the senses and control the urges of desire and anger before giving up this body, he is well situated and is happy in this world.
verses.transliteration: śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṁ prāk śarīra-vimokṣaṇāt kāma-krodhodbhavaṁ vegaṁ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes that true happiness and stability come from controlling the urges of desire and anger before death.

verses.sanskrit: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः। स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति॥
verses.translation: One whose happiness is within, who is active and rejoices within, and whose aim is inward, is actually the perfect mystic. He is liberated in the Supreme, and ultimately he attains to the Supreme.
verses.transliteration: yo 'ntaḥ-sukho 'ntar-ārāmas tathāntar-jyotir eva yaḥ sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṁ brahma-bhūto 'dhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the perfect mystic as one who finds happiness and joy within and is focused inward, attaining liberation in the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः। छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥
verses.translation: Those whose minds are fixed on the Supreme are liberated from material contamination. They are in a trance of self-realization. They are always engaged in working for the welfare of all living beings.
verses.transliteration: labhante brahma-nirvāṇam ṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ chinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna portrays liberated sages as those who are free from impurities and duality, are self-realized, and work for the welfare of all beings.

verses.sanskrit: अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम्। क्रोधामिनो वियुक्तानां यतात्मनां विजितात्मनाम्॥
verses.translation: Those who are free from anger and all material desires, who are self-realized, self-disciplined and constantly endeavoring for perfection, are assured of liberation in the Supreme in the near future.
verses.transliteration: abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṁ vartate viditātmanām krodhābhito viyuktānāṁ yatātmānāṁ vijitātmanām
verses.meaning: Krishna states that those free from anger and desires, who are self-realized and disciplined, are assured of liberation in the Supreme soon.

verses.sanskrit: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्याश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः। प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ॥
verses.translation: Shutting out all external sense objects, keeping the eyes and vision concentrated between the two eyebrows, suspending the inward and outward breaths within the nostrils—and thus controlling the mind, senses and intelligence, the transcendentalist aiming at liberation becomes free forever. He is sure to attain liberation.
verses.transliteration: sparśān kṛtvā bahir bāhyāś cakṣuś caivāntare bhruvoḥ prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantara-cāriṇau
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the practice of controlling the senses, focusing the eyes and breath, to achieve liberation.

verses.sanskrit: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः। विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः॥
verses.translation: (continuation of previous verse)...
verses.transliteration: yatendriya-mano-buddhir munir mokṣa-parāyaṇaḥ vigatecchā-bhaya-krodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ
verses.meaning: (continuation of previous verse)... This verse continues describing the state of the transcendentalist who controls senses, mind, and intelligence, ultimately achieving liberation.

verses.sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्। सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति॥
verses.translation: The sages, knowing Me as the ultimate purpose of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all planets and demigods, and the benefactor and well-wisher of all living entities, attain freedom from material pains.
verses.transliteration: bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ sarva-loka-maheśvaram suhṛdaṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śāntim ṛcchati
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by saying that knowing him as the enjoyer of all sacrifices, the Supreme Lord, and the well-wisher of all beings leads to peace.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः। स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: One who is unattached to the fruits of his work and who works as he is obliged is in the renounced order of life, and he is the true mystic, not he who merely lights no fire and performs no work.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca anāśritaḥ karma-phalaṁ kāryaṁ karma karoti yaḥ sa sannyāsī ca yogī ca na niragnir na cākriyaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna defines a true renunciant and mystic as one who performs their duty without attachment to the results, not merely one who abstains from rituals or work.

verses.sanskrit: यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव। न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन॥
verses.translation: What is called renunciation is the same as yoga, or linking oneself with the Supreme, for no one can become a yogī unless he renounces the desire for sense gratification.
verses.transliteration: yaṁ sannyāsam iti prāhur yogaṁ taṁ viddhi pāṇḍava na hy asaṁnyasta-saṅkalpo yogī bhavati kaścana
verses.meaning: Krishna equates true renunciation with yoga, emphasizing that renouncing desires is essential for becoming a yogi.

verses.sanskrit: आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते। योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते॥
verses.translation: For one who is a neophyte in the yoga system, work is said to be the means; and for one who is already elevated in yoga, cessation of all material activity is said to be the means.
verses.transliteration: ārurukṣor muner yogaṁ karma kāraṇam ucyate yogārūḍhasya tasyaiva śamaḥ kāraṇam ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the path of yoga, stating that action is the means for a beginner, while cessation of action is the means for one advanced in yoga.

verses.sanskrit: यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते। सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते॥
verses.translation: A person is said to be elevated in yoga when he has given up all material desires and has no interest in fruitive activities. He is said to be situated in steadfast transcendence.
verses.transliteration: yadā hi nendriyārtheṣu na karmasv anuṣajjate sarva-saṅkalpa-sannyāsī yogārūḍhas tadocyate
verses.meaning: Krishna defines a person established in yoga as one who has renounced all material desires and is indifferent to the fruits of action.

verses.sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्। आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः॥
verses.translation: One must deliver himself with the help of his mind, and not degrade himself. The mind is the friend of the conditioned soul, and his enemy as well.
verses.transliteration: uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna stresses the importance of self-deliverance through the mind, explaining that the mind can be both a friend and an enemy.

verses.sanskrit: बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः। अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्॥
verses.translation: For him who has conquered the mind, the mind is the best of friends; but for one who has failed to do so, his mind will remain his greatest enemy.
verses.transliteration: bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ anātmanas tu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat
verses.meaning: Krishna elaborates on the dual nature of the mind, stating that it is a friend to one who has conquered it, but an enemy to one who has not.

verses.sanskrit: जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः। शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः॥
verses.translation: For one who has conquered the mind, the Supersoul is already reached. He has attained peace, and he is not affected by duality like heat and cold, happiness and distress, honor and dishonor.
verses.transliteration: jitātmanaḥ praśāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu tathā māna-apamānayoḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the characteristics of one who has conquered the mind and attained the Supersoul, remaining undisturbed by dualities.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः। युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः॥
verses.translation: A person is said to be established in self-realization and is called a yogī [or mystic] when he is fully satisfied by virtue of acquired knowledge and realization. Such a person is situated in transcendence and is self-controlled. He sees everything—whether pebbles, stones or gold—as the same.
verses.transliteration: jñāna-vijñāna-tṛptātmā kūṭa-stho vijitendriyaḥ yukta ity ucyate yogī sama-loṣṭrāśma-kāñcanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna defines a self-realized yogi as one who is satisfied with knowledge, self-controlled, and views everything with equanimity.

verses.sanskrit: सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु। समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते॥
verses.translation: A person is considered still further advanced when he regards honest well-wishers, affectionate benefactors, those who are neutral, mediators, enemies, friends, the envious, and the relatives and the pious alike.
verses.transliteration: suhṛn-mitrāry-udāsīna-madhyastha-dveṣya-bandhuṣu sama-buddhir viśiṣyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes an even more advanced person as one who maintains equanimity towards all, including friends, enemies, and neutrals.

verses.sanskrit: योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः। एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः॥
verses.translation: The transcendentalist should always engage his body, mind and self in relationship with the Supreme; he should live alone in a secluded place and always carefully control his mind. He should be free from desires and feelings of possessiveness.
verses.transliteration: yogī yuñjīta satatam ātmānaṁ rahasi sthitaḥ ekākī yata-cittātmā nirāśīr aparigrahaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna outlines the conditions for practicing yoga: living in seclusion, controlling the mind, and being free from desires and possessiveness.

verses.sanskrit: शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः। नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम्॥
verses.translation: To practice yoga, one should go to a secluded place and should lay kusa grass on the ground and then cover it with a deerskin and a soft cloth. The seat should neither be too high nor too low and should be situated in a sacred place.
verses.transliteration: śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiram āsanam ātmanaḥ nāty-ucchritaṁ nāti-nīcaṁ cailājina-kuśottaram
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the appropriate setting and seat for practicing yoga.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः। उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये॥
verses.translation: There the yogī should sit with his body, neck and head held straight, gazing at the tip of his nose. Thus, with restrained mind, regulating his activities, he should sit down to practice yoga to purify existence.
verses.transliteration: tatraikāgraṁ manaḥ kṛtvā yata-cittendriya-kriyaḥ upaviśyāsane yuñjyād yogam ātma-viśuddhaye
verses.meaning: Krishna instructs on the posture and focus required for practicing yoga to purify the self.

verses.sanskrit: समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः। संप्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन्॥
verses.translation: (same as previous verse)
verses.transliteration: samaṁ kāya-śiro-grīvaṁ dhārayann acalaṁ sthiraḥ samprekṣya nāsikāgraṁ svaṁ diśaś cānavalokayan
verses.meaning: (same as previous verse) This verse continues the description of the correct posture and focus during yoga practice.

verses.sanskrit: प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः। मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः॥
verses.translation: The result is that with mind steady, controlled and without fear, completely free from material contamination, one's mind is fixed on Me.
verses.transliteration: praśāntātmā vigata-bhīr brahmacāri-vrate sthitaḥ manaḥ saṁyamya mac-citto yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the mental state of a yogi: peaceful, fearless, and focused on him.

verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः। शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति॥
verses.translation: Thus practicing constant control of the body, mind and activities, the mystic transcendentalist, his mind regulated, attains to the kingdom of God [or the abode of Kṛṣṇa] by cessation of material existence.
verses.transliteration: yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī niyata-mānasaḥ śāntiṁ nirvāṇa-paramāṁ mat-saṁsthām adhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that by consistently controlling the body and mind, a yogi attains the supreme peace in the kingdom of God.

verses.sanskrit: नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः। न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन॥
verses.translation: There is no possibility of one's becoming a yogī, O Arjuna, if one eats too much or eats too little, sleeps too much or does not sleep enough.
verses.transliteration: nāty-aśnatas tu yogo 'sti na caikāntam anaśnataḥ na cāti-svapna-śīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna
verses.meaning: Krishna advises on moderation in eating and sleeping for successful yoga practice.

verses.sanskrit: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु। युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा॥
verses.translation: He who is regulated in his habits of eating, sleeping, recreation and work can mitigate all material pains by practicing the yoga system.
verses.transliteration: yuktāhāra-vihārasya yukta-ceṣṭasya karmasu yukta-svapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkha-hā
verses.meaning: Krishna outlines that regulating eating, recreation, work, and sleep can alleviate material suffering through yoga.

verses.sanskrit: यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते। निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा॥
verses.translation: When the yogī, by practice of yoga, disciplines his mental activities and becomes situated in transcendence—devoid of all material desires—he is said to be well established in yoga.
verses.transliteration: yadā viniyataṁ cittam ātmany evāvatiṣṭhate niḥspṛhaḥ sarva-kāmebhyo yukta ity ucyate tadā
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the state of a yogi whose mind is disciplined and fixed in transcendence, free from material desires.

verses.sanskrit: यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता। योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः॥
verses.translation: As a lamp in a windless place does not waver, so the transcendentalist, whose mind is controlled, remains always steady in his meditation on the Supreme Self.
verses.transliteration: yathā dīpo nivāta-stho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā yogino yata-cittasya yuñjato yogam ātmanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna uses the analogy of a steady lamp to illustrate the unwavering focus of a yogi in meditation.

verses.sanskrit: यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया। यत्र चैवात्मनात्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति॥
verses.translation: In the stage of perfection called trance, or samādhi, one's mind is completely restrained from material mental activities by the practice of yoga. By this perfection one is able to see the Self by his pure mind and to relish and rejoice in the Self.
verses.transliteration: yatroparamate cittaṁ niruddhaṁ yoga-sevayā yatra caivātmanātmānaṁ paśyann ātmani tuṣyati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the state of samadhi, where the mind is completely restrained, and one experiences self-realization and satisfaction.

verses.sanskrit: सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद् बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम्। वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः॥
verses.translation: In that joyous state, one is situated in boundless transcendental happiness, realized through transcendental intelligence. Thus established, one never departs from the truth.
verses.transliteration: sukham ātyantikaṁ yat tad buddhi-grāhyam atīndriyam vetti yatra na caivāyaṁ sthitaś calati tattvataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that in this state, one experiences infinite transcendental happiness and remains firm in the truth.

verses.sanskrit: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः। यस्मिन् स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते॥
verses.translation: Upon gaining this position, one thinks there is no greater gain, and one remains situated in such a position that even in the midst of greatest distress one is never shaken.
verses.transliteration: yaṁ labdhvā cāparaṁ lābhaṁ manyate nādhikaṁ tataḥ yasmin sthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the stability and contentment of one who has attained this state, remaining unshaken even in great distress.

verses.sanskrit: तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्॥
verses.translation: That which was previously described as detachment of the self from the contact of matter is really the yoga system.
verses.transliteration: taṁ vidyād duḥkha-saṁyoga-viyogaṁ yoga-saṁjñitam
verses.meaning: Krishna defines yoga as the detachment of the self from contact with matter.

verses.sanskrit: स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा। सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः। मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः॥
verses.translation: One should engage in the practice of yoga with determination and faith and not be deviated from the path. One should abandon, without exception, all material desires born of mental speculation and thus control all the senses on all sides by use of the mind.
verses.transliteration: sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo 'nirviṇṇa-cetasā saṅkalpa-prabhavān kāmāṁs tyaktvā sarvān aśeṣataḥ manasaivendriya-grāmaṁ viniyamya samantataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna advises practicing yoga with determination and faith, abandoning all material desires, and controlling the senses with the mind.

verses.sanskrit: शनैः शनैरुपरमेद् बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया। आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किंचिदपि चिन्तयेत्॥
verses.translation: Gradually, step by step, one should become situated in trance by means of intelligence sustained by determination, and thus the mind should be fixed on the Self alone and should think of nothing else.
verses.transliteration: śanaiḥ śanair uparamed buddhyā dhṛti-gṛhītayā ātma-saṁsthaṁ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiñcid api cintayet
verses.meaning: Krishna recommends a gradual process of attaining trance through determination and fixing the mind on the Self, thinking of nothing else.

verses.sanskrit: यतो यतो निश्चलति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम्। ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत्॥
verses.translation: From wherever the mind wanders due to its flickering and unsteady nature, one must certainly withdraw it and bring it back under the control of the Self.
verses.transliteration: yato yato niścalati manaś cañcalam asthiram tatas tato niyamyaitad ātmany eva vaśaṁ nayet
verses.meaning: Krishna advises to persistently redirect the wandering mind back to the Self.

verses.sanskrit: प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम्। उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम्॥
verses.translation: The yogī whose mind is fixed on Me verily attains the highest perfection of transcendental happiness. He is beyond the mode of passion, he realizes his qualitative identity with the Supreme, and he is freed from all past reactions.
verses.transliteration: praśānta-manasaṁ hy enaṁ yoginaṁ sukham uttamam upaiti śānta-rajasaṁ brahma-bhūtam akalmaṣam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the yogi with a fixed mind as attaining supreme happiness, transcending passion, realizing oneness with the Supreme, and becoming free from past karma.

verses.sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः। सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते॥
verses.translation: Thus the self-controlled yogī, constantly engaged in yoga practice, becomes free from all material contamination and achieves the highest perfectional stage of happiness in oneness with the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
verses.transliteration: yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī vigata-kalmaṣaḥ sukhena brahma-saṁsparśam atyantaṁ sukham aśnute
verses.meaning: Krishna reiterates that a self-controlled yogi, through constant practice, attains the highest happiness in union with the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि। ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः॥
verses.translation: A true yogī observes Me in all beings and also sees every being in Me. Indeed, the self-realized man sees Me everywhere.
verses.transliteration: sarva-bhūta-stham ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāni cātmani īkṣate yoga-yuktātmā sarvatra sama-darśanaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a true yogi as one who sees him in all beings and all beings in him, perceiving him everywhere with equanimity.

verses.sanskrit: यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति। तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति॥
verses.translation: For one who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, I am never lost, nor is he ever lost to Me.
verses.transliteration: yo māṁ paśyati sarvatra sarvaṁ ca mayi paśyati tasyāhaṁ na praṇaśyāmi sa ca me na praṇaśyati
verses.meaning: Krishna affirms that he is never lost to one who sees him everywhere, and that person is never lost to him.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः। सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते॥
verses.translation: Such a yogī, who engages in the worshipful service of the Supersoul, knowing that I and the Supersoul are one, remains always in Me in all circumstances.
verses.transliteration: sarva-bhūta-sthitaṁ yo māṁ bhajaty ekatvam āsthitaḥ sarvathā vartamāno 'pi sa yogī mayi vartate
verses.meaning: Krishna states that a yogi who worships the Supersoul, knowing their oneness with him, always remains in him, regardless of their circumstances.

verses.sanskrit: आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन। सुखं यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः॥
verses.translation: He is a perfect yogī who, by comparison to his own self, sees the true equality of all beings, in both their happiness and their distress, O Arjuna!
verses.transliteration: ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṁ paśyati yo 'rjuna sukhaṁ yadi vā duḥkhaṁ sa yogī paramo mataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna defines a perfect yogi as one who sees the equality of all beings in happiness and distress, by comparing them to his own self.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन। एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात्स्थितिं स्थिराम्॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Madhusūdana, the system of yoga which You describe appears impractical and unendurable to me, for the mind is restless and unsteady.
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca yo 'yaṁ yogas tvayā proktaḥ sāmyena madhusūdana etasyāhaṁ na paśyāmi cañcalatvāt sthitiṁ sthirām
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his doubt about the practicality and endurance of yoga due to the restless nature of the mind.

verses.sanskrit: चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद् दृढम्। तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम्॥
verses.translation: For the mind is restless, turbulent, obstinate and very strong, O Krishna, and to subdue it, I think, is more difficult than controlling the wind.
verses.transliteration: cañcalaṁ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham tasyāhaṁ nigrahaṁ manye vāyor iva su-duṣkaram
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the mind as restless, turbulent, obstinate, and strong, making it very difficult to control—even more so than controlling the wind.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम्। अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: O mighty-armed son of Kunti, it is undoubtedly very difficult to curb the restless mind, but it is possible by suitable practice and by detachment.
verses.transliteration: aśayaṁ mahā-bāho mano dur-nigrahaṁ calam abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate
verses.meaning: Krishna acknowledges the difficulty in controlling the mind but assures Arjuna that it can be achieved through practice and detachment.

verses.sanskrit: असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः। वश्यतात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः॥
verses.translation: For one whose mind is unbridled, self-realization is difficult. But he whose mind is controlled and who strives by appropriate means is assured of success.
verses.transliteration: asaṁyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ vaśyatātmanā tu yatatā śakyo 'vāptum upāyataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna says that self-realization is hard for the uncontrolled mind, but the controlled mind, through proper effort, is assured of success.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः। अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति॥
verses.translation: Arjuna inquired: O Krishna, what is the destination of the unsuccessful transcendentalist, who in the beginning takes to the process of self-realization with faith but later desists due to worldly-mindedness and is thus unable to reach perfection in yoga?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca ayatiḥ śraddhayopeto yogāc calita-mānasaḥ aprāpya yoga-saṁsiddhiṁ kāṁ gatiṁ kṛṣṇa gacchati
verses.meaning: Arjuna asks about the fate of one who starts the path of self-realization with faith but fails to reach perfection due to a worldly mind.

verses.sanskrit: कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्र इव नश्यति। अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि॥
verses.translation: O mighty-armed Krishna, does he not fall away from both spiritual and material success and perish like a torn cloud, with no position in any sphere?
verses.transliteration: kaccin nobhaya-vibhraṣṭaś chinnābhra iva naśyati apratiṣṭho mahā-bāho vimūḍho brahmaṇaḥ pathi
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses concern that such a person might lose both spiritual and material gains, like a torn cloud with no support.

verses.sanskrit: एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः। त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते॥
verses.translation: O Krishna, this is my doubt. Please dispel it completely. For no one but You can destroy this doubt.
verses.transliteration: etan me saṁśayaṁ kṛṣṇa chettum arhasy aśeṣataḥ tvad-anyaḥ saṁśayasyāsya chettā na hy upapadyate
verses.meaning: Arjuna asks Krishna to completely dispel his doubt, as he believes that only Krishna can resolve it.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते। न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद् दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: O son of Pṛthā, a transcendentalist engaged in auspicious activities does not meet with destruction either in this world or in the spiritual world; one who does good, My friend, is never overcome by evil.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca pārtha naiveha nāmutra vināśas tasya vidyate na hi kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṁ tāta gacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna reassures Arjuna that a person engaged in auspicious activities is never destroyed, either in this world or the next; one who does good never meets evil.

verses.sanskrit: प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः। सूचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते॥
verses.translation: The unsuccessful yogī, after many, many years of enjoyment on the planets of the pious, is born into a family of righteous people, or into a family of rich aristocracy.
verses.transliteration: prāpya puṇya-kṛtāṁ lokān uṣitvā śāśvatīḥ samāḥ śucīnāṁ śrīmatāṁ gehe yoga-bhraṣṭo 'bhijāyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that an unsuccessful yogi is reborn into a righteous or wealthy family after enjoying time on the planets of the pious.

verses.sanskrit: अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम्। एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम्॥
verses.translation: Or [if unsuccessful after long practice of yoga] he takes his birth in a family of transcendentalists who are surely great in wisdom. Certainly such a birth is rare in this world.
verses.transliteration: athavā yoginām eva kule bhavati dhīmatām etad dhi durlabhataraṁ loke janma yad īdṛśam
verses.meaning: Krishna adds that an unsuccessful yogi may also be born into a family of wise transcendentalists, which is a very rare occurrence.

verses.sanskrit: तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम्। यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन॥
verses.translation: On taking such a birth, he revives the divine consciousness of his previous life, and he again tries to make further progress in order to achieve complete success, O son of Kuru.
verses.transliteration: tatra taṁ buddhi-saṁyogaṁ labhate paurva-dehikam yatate ca tato bhūyaḥ saṁsiddhau kuru-nandana
verses.meaning: Krishna says that in such a birth, the individual revives their past spiritual consciousness and strives again for complete success in self-realization.

verses.sanskrit: पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः। जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते॥
verses.translation: By virtue of the divine consciousness of his previous life, he is automatically attracted to the yogic principles—even without seeking them. Such an inquisitive transcendentalist stands always above the ritualistic principles of the scriptures.
verses.transliteration: pūrvābhyāsena tenaiva hriyate hy avaśo 'pi saḥ jijñāsur api yogasya śabda-brahmātivartate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that due to past practice, such a person is naturally drawn to yoga and transcends the ritualistic principles of the scriptures.

verses.sanskrit: प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः। अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम्॥
verses.translation: And when the yogī engages himself with sincere endeavor in further advancement, being washed of all contaminations, he eventually achieves perfection after many, many births, and at last attains the supreme goal.
verses.transliteration: prayatnād yatamānas tu yogī saṁśuddha-kilbiṣaḥ aneka-janma-saṁsiddhas tato yāti parāṁ gatim
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes that a yogi who strives sincerely, becoming purified of all impurities through many births, eventually reaches the supreme goal.

verses.sanskrit: तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः। कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन॥
verses.translation: A yogī is greater than the ascetic, greater than the empiricist and greater than the fruitive worker. Therefore, O Arjuna, be a yogī.
verses.transliteration: tapasvibhyo 'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo 'pi mato 'dhikaḥ karmibhyaś cādhiko yogī tasmād yogī bhavārjuna
verses.meaning: Krishna emphasizes the superiority of a yogi over ascetics, empiricists, and those seeking fruitive results, and urges Arjuna to become a yogi.

verses.sanskrit: योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना। श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः॥
verses.translation: And of all yogīs, the one with great faith who always abides in Me, thinks of Me within himself, and renders transcendental loving service to Me is the most intimately united with Me in yoga and is the highest of all. That is My opinion.
verses.transliteration: yoginām api sarveṣāṁ mad-gatenāntarātmanā śraddhāvān bhajate yo māṁ sa me yuktatamo mataḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by stating that the yogi who, with great faith, always thinks of him within and renders loving service is the most intimately united with him and is the highest of all yogis.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः। असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Now hear, O son of Pṛthā, how by practicing yoga in full consciousness of Me, with mind attached to Me, you can know Me in full, free from all doubts.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca mayy āsakta-manāḥ pārtha yogaṁ yuñjan mad-āśrayaḥ asanshayaṁ samagraṁ māṁ yathā jñāsyasi tac chṛṇu
verses.meaning: Krishna begins by instructing Arjuna on how to know Him fully and without doubt, by practicing yoga with a mind attached to Him.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः। यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते॥
