verses.translation: If hundreds of thousands of suns were to rise at once in the sky, their combined light might resemble the effulgence of the Supreme Person in that universal form.
verses.transliteration: divi sūrya-sahasrasya bhaved yugapad utthitā yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syāt tasya bhāsaḥ mahātmanaḥ
verses.meaning: The splendor of the universal form is compared to the light of a simultaneous rising of thousands of suns.

verses.sanskrit: तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा। अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा॥
verses.translation: At that time Arjuna saw in the universal form of the Lord the unlimited expansions of the universe situated in one place, although divided into many, many thousands.
verses.transliteration: tatraika-sthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ pravibhaktam anekadhā apaśyad deva-devasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā
verses.meaning: Arjuna witnesses the entire universe, with its countless divisions, contained within the universal form of the Lord.

verses.sanskrit: ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः। प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत॥
verses.translation: Then, bewildered and astonished, his hair standing on end, Arjuna bowed his head and began to pray with folded hands.
verses.transliteration: tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭa-romā dhanañjayaḥ praṇamya śirasā devaṁ kṛtāñjalir abhāṣata
verses.meaning: Overwhelmed with wonder and awe, Arjuna bows his head, folds his hands, and begins to offer prayers.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान्। ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थमृषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान्॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: My dear Lord, O Supreme Personality of Godhead, I see in Your body all the demigods and various other living entities assembled. I see Brahmā, as well as Lord Śiva, all the great sages, and the celestial serpents.
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca paśyāmi devāṁs tava deva dehe sarvāṁs tathā bhūta-viśeṣa-saṅghān brahmāṇam īśaṁ kamalāsanastham ṛṣīṁś ca sarvān uragāṁś ca divyān
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes seeing various demigods, living entities, Brahma, Shiva, great sages, and celestial serpents in Krishna's universal form.

verses.sanskrit: अनेकबाहुदरवक्त्रनेत्रं पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम्। अन्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप॥
verses.translation: O Lord of the universe, O universal form, I see in Your body many, many arms, bellies, mouths and eyes, expanded everywhere, without limit. I see in You no end, no middle and no beginning.
verses.transliteration: aneka-bāhūdara-vaktra-netraṁ paśyāmi tvāṁ sarvato 'nanta-rūpam antaṁ na madhyaṁ na punas tavādiṁ paśyāmi viśveśvara viśva-rūpa
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his awe at the unlimited form of Krishna, seeing His countless arms, bellies, mouths, and eyes, and perceiving no beginning, middle, or end.

verses.sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम्। पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं सर्वत दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम्॥
verses.translation: I see You with crowns, clubs and discs. Your splendor is everywhere, an unbearable blazing fire whose radiance fills the universe.
verses.transliteration: kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ cakriṇaṁ ca tejo-rāśiṁ sarvato dīptimantam paśyāmi tvāṁ durnirīkṣyaṁ sarvato dīptānalārka-dyutim aprameyam
verses.meaning: Arjuna sees Krishna adorned with crowns, clubs, and discs, His splendor filling the universe with an intense, immeasurable radiance.

verses.sanskrit: त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्। त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे॥
verses.translation: You are the inexhaustible, the supreme goal of realization. You are the support of this entire universe. You are the imperishable, the supreme goal, and the eternal sustainer of religion. I think that You are the Supreme Person.
verses.transliteration: tvam akṣaraṁ paramaṁ veditavyaṁ tvam asya viśvasya paraṁ nidhānam tvam avyayaḥ śāśvata-dharma-goptā sanātanas tvaṁ puruṣo mato me
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the Lord as the inexhaustible Supreme, the ultimate support of the universe, the imperishable, the eternal sustainer of religion, and the Supreme Person.

verses.sanskrit: अनादिमध्यपर्यन्तमनन्तवीर्यमनन्तबाहुमसंख्येयचक्षुषम्। त्वां पश्यामि सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपमादिमध्यं च पुन: पुन:॥
verses.translation: You have no beginning, no middle, no end; Your glory is unlimited. Your arms are infinite. Your eyes are countless. I see this cosmic form of Yours extending everywhere.
verses.transliteration: anādi-madhyānta-mananta-vīryam ananta-bāhum asankhya-cakṣuṣam tvāṁ paśyāmi sarvato 'nanta-rūpam ādi-madhyaṁ ca punaḥ punaḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna continues to describe the universal form, noting its lack of beginning, middle, or end, its infinite power, arms, and eyes, and its presence everywhere.

verses.sanskrit: द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः। दृष्ट्वाद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं त्रिलोक्यं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन्॥
verses.translation: By You alone are the space between the earth and the sky and all the directions pervaded. O great one, having seen this wondrous, terrible form of Yours, all the three worlds are trembling.
verses.transliteration: dyāv-āpṛthivyor idam antaraṁ hi vyāptaṁ tvayaikena diśaś ca sarvāḥ dṛṣṭvādbhutaṁ rūpam ugraṁ tavedaṁ tri-lokyaṁ pravyathitaṁ mahātman
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes how the Lord alone pervades the entire space and all directions, and how the three worlds tremble at the sight of His wondrous and terrible form.

verses.sanskrit: अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति। स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसङ्घाः स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभिः पुष्कलाभिः॥
verses.translation: The hosts of demigods are entering into You. Some of them, very much afraid, are offering prayers with joined hands. Hosts of great sages and perfected beings, crying, “May there be peace!” are praising You with profuse hymns.
verses.transliteration: amī hi tvāṁ sura-saṅghā viśanti kecid bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti svastīty uktvā maharṣi-siddha-saṅghāḥ stuvanti tvāṁ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna observes demigods entering the Lord, some afraid and offering prayers, while hosts of sages and perfected beings praise Him with hymns, wishing peace.

verses.sanskrit: रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या विश्वेऽश्विनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च। गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसङ्घा वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे॥
verses.translation: All the various manifestations of Rudras, Ādityas, Vasus, Sādhyas, Viśvedevas, Aśvins, Maruts and forefathers; and the Gandharvas, Yakṣas, Asuras and perfected demigods are beholding You in wonder.
verses.transliteration: rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā viśve 'śvinau marutaś coṣmapāś ca gandharva-yakṣāsura-siddha-saṅghā vīkṣante tvāṁ vismitāś caiva sarve
verses.meaning: Arjuna sees various groups of beings, including Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, and other demigods, along with Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and perfected beings, all beholding the Lord in wonder.

verses.sanskrit: रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम्। बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाहम्॥
verses.translation: O mighty-armed, all the planets with their demigods are agitated at seeing Your many faces, eyes, arms, thighs, feet, and Your terrible teeth. And as they are agitated, so am I.
verses.transliteration: rūpaṁ mahat te bahu-vaktra-netraṁ mahā-bāho bahu-bāhūru-pādam bahūdaraṁ bahu-daṁṣṭrā-karālaṁ dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitās tathāham
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the universal form as having many faces, eyes, arms, thighs, and feet, and terrible teeth, which agitate both the planets and himself.

verses.sanskrit: नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम्। दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो॥
verses.translation: O Viṣṇu, seeing You with Your many radiant colors touching the sky, with mouths opened wide and with large, shining eyes, my mind is perturbed. I can find neither tranquility nor peace.
verses.transliteration: nabhaḥ-spṛśaṁ dīptam aneka-varṇaṁ vyāttānanaṁ dīpta-viśāla-netram dṛṣṭvā hi tvāṁ pravyathitāntarātmā dhṛtiṁ na vindāmi śamaṁ ca viṣṇo
verses.meaning: Arjuna expresses his perturbation upon seeing the Lord's form, which touches the sky with radiant colors, wide-open mouths, and large, shining eyes, and finds no tranquility or peace.

verses.sanskrit: दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि। दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास॥
verses.translation: O Lord of lords, O abode of the universe, after seeing Your mouths with terrible teeth, like the fire of devastation, I am bewildered. I know not which way to turn. Therefore I beg You to be gracious.
verses.transliteration: daṁṣṭrā-karālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvaiva kālānala-sannibhāni diśo na jāne na labhe ca śarma prasīda deveśa jagan-nivāsa
verses.meaning: Arjuna, bewildered by the sight of the Lord's mouths with terrible teeth resembling the fire of devastation, seeks His grace, not knowing which way to turn.

verses.sanskrit: अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसङ्घैः। भीष्मद्रोणः सूतपुत्रस्तथासौ सहस्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यैः॥
verses.translation: All the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra along with their allied kings, and Bhīṣma, Droṇa, Karṇa—and also our chief soldiers—
verses.transliteration: amī ca tvāṁ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve sahaivāvani-pāla-saṅghaiḥ bhīṣma-droṇaḥ sūta-putras tathāsau saha-asmadīyair api yodha-mukhyaiḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the scene of the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with their allied kings, Bhishma, Drona, Karna, and the chief soldiers from both sides, entering the Lord's mouths.

verses.sanskrit: वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयानकानि। केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु सन्दृश्यन्ते चूर्णितानि उत्तमाङ्गैः॥
verses.translation: are rushing into Your fearful mouths. And some, with their heads crushed, are seen stuck between Your teeth.
verses.transliteration: vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti daṁṣṭrā-karālāni bhayānakāni kecid vilagnā daśanāntareṣu sandṛśyante cūrṇitāni uttamāṅgaiḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna further details how some are rushing into the Lord's fearful mouths with terrible teeth, and some are seen with their heads crushed, stuck between His teeth.

verses.sanskrit: यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति। तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति॥
verses.translation: As the rivers flow into the roaring ocean, so do all these heroes of the mortal world enter Your blazing mouths.
verses.transliteration: yathā nadīnāṁ bahavo 'mbu-vegāḥ samudram evābhimukhā dravanti tathā tavāmī nara-loka-vīrā viśanti vaktrāṇy abhivijvalanti
verses.meaning: Arjuna compares the warriors of the mortal world entering the Lord's blazing mouths to rivers flowing into the ocean.

verses.sanskrit: यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः। तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोकास्तव वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः॥
verses.translation: I see all people rushing full speed into Your mouths, as moths dash into a blazing fire.
verses.transliteration: yathā pradīptaṁ jvalanaṁ pataṅgā viśanti nāśāya samṛddha-vegāḥ tathāiva nāśāya viśanti lokās tava vaktrāṇi samṛddha-vegāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna observes people rushing into the Lord's mouths for destruction, similar to moths flying into a blazing fire.

verses.sanskrit: लिलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्ताल्लोकान्समग्रान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः। तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो॥
verses.translation: O Viṣṇu, I see You devouring all people from all sides with Your flaming mouths. Your terrible rays are filling this entire universe with radiance.
verses.transliteration: lilihyaṣe grasamānaḥ samantāl lokān samagrān vadanair jvaladbhiḥ tejobhir āpūrya jagat samagraṁ bhāsas tava ugrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo
verses.meaning: Arjuna describes the Lord devouring everyone with His flaming mouths, His terrible rays filling the universe with intense radiance.

verses.sanskrit: आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद। विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम्॥
verses.translation: O Lord of lords, so fierce of form, please tell me who You are. I offer my obeisances unto You; be gracious to me. I wish to know You, the original Personality of Godhead. I am bewildered about Your activities.
verses.transliteration: ākhyāhi me ko bhavān ugra-rūpo namo 'stu te deva-vara prasīda vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyaṁ na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim
verses.meaning: Arjuna, bewildered by the Lord's fierce form, asks Him to reveal His identity and intentions, offering his obeisances and seeking His grace.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्तास्त्वां पर्युपासते। ये चाप्यक्षरमव्यक्तं तेषां के योगवित्तमाः॥
verses.translation: Arjuna inquired: Which is considered to be more perfect: those who are always properly engaged in Your devotional service or those who worship the impersonal, unmanifested Brahman?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca evaṁ satata-yuktā ye bhaktās tvāṁ paryupāsate ye cāpy akṣaram avyaktaṁ teṣāṁ ke yoga-vittamāḥ
verses.meaning: Arjuna asks Krishna about the superiority of those devoted to His personal form versus those who worship the impersonal Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। मय्यावेश्य मनो ये मां नित्ययुक्ता उपासते। श्रद्धया परयोपेतास्ते मे युक्ततमा मताः॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Those who fix their minds on My personal form and are always engaged in worshiping Me with great transcendental faith are considered by Me to be most perfect.
verses.transliteration: mayy āveśya mano ye māṁ nitya-yuktā upāsate śraddhayā parayopetās te me yuktatamā matāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna declares that those who fix their minds on His personal form and worship Him with faith are most perfect.

verses.sanskrit: ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते। सर्वत्रगमचिन्त्यं च कूटस्थमचलं ध्रुवम्॥
verses.translation: But those who fully worship the unmanifested, that which lies beyond the perception of the senses, the all-pervading, inconceivable, unchanging, fixed and immovable—the impersonal conception of the Absolute Truth—
verses.transliteration: ye tv akṣaram anirdeśyam avyaktaṁ paryupāsate sarvatra-gam acintyaṁ ca kūṭa-stham acalaṁ dhruvam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes those who worship the impersonal, unmanifested, all-pervading, and unchanging Absolute Truth.

verses.sanskrit: संनियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः। ते प्राप्नुवन्ति मामेव सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥
verses.translation: By controlling the senses and being equally disposed to everyone, such persons, engaged in the welfare of all, at last achieve Me.
verses.transliteration: saṁniyamyendriya-grāmaṁ sarvatra sama-buddhayaḥ te prāpnuvanti mām eva sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna says that those who control their senses, are equally disposed to all, and work for the welfare of all also attain Him.

verses.sanskrit: क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्। अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाप्यते॥
verses.translation: For those whose minds are attached to the unmanifested, impersonal feature of the Supreme, advancement is very troublesome. To make progress in that discipline is always difficult for those who are embodied.
verses.transliteration: kleśo 'dhikataras teṣām avyaktāsakta-cetasām avyaktā hi gatir duḥkhaṁ dehavadbhir avāpyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that progress is difficult for embodied beings who are attached to the impersonal, unmanifested aspect.

verses.sanskrit: ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः। अनन्येनैव योगेन मां ध्यायन्त उपासते॥
verses.translation: But those who worship Me, giving up all their activities to Me and devoting themselves to Me without reservation, remaining ever fixed in devotional service, meditating on Me,
verses.transliteration: ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi saṁnyasya mat-parāḥ ananyenaiva yogena māṁ dhyāyanta upāsate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes those who worship Him by dedicating all their actions to Him, being devoted to Him without reservation, and constantly meditating on Him.

verses.sanskrit: तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात्। भवामि नचिरात्पार्थ मय्यावेशितचेतसाम्॥
verses.translation: O son of Pṛthā, for those who always fix their minds on Me, I am the swift deliverer from the ocean of birth and death.
verses.transliteration: teṣām ahaṁ samuddhartā mṛtyu-saṁsāra-sāgarāt bhavāmi na cirāt pārtha mayy āveśita-cetasām
verses.meaning: Krishna promises to swiftly deliver from the cycle of birth and death those who fix their minds on Him.

verses.sanskrit: मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय। निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः॥
verses.translation: Just fix your mind upon Me and engage all your intelligence in Me. Thus you will live in Me always, without a doubt.
verses.transliteration: mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṁ niveśaya nivasiṣyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṁ na saṁśayaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna advises Arjuna to fix his mind and intelligence upon Him to live with Him always.

verses.sanskrit: अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम्। अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छ प्राप्तुं धनंजय॥
verses.translation: My dear Arjuna, if you cannot fix your mind upon Me without deviation, then follow the regulative principles of bhakti-yoga. In this way develop a desire to attain Me.
verses.transliteration: atha cittaṁ samādhātuṁ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram abhyāsa-yogena tato mām icchāptuṁ dhanañjaya
verses.meaning: Krishna suggests that if Arjuna cannot fix his mind on Him, he should follow the principles of Bhakti-yoga to develop a desire to attain Him.

verses.sanskrit: अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव। मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन्सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि॥
verses.translation: If you cannot practice the regulative principles of bhakti-yoga, then just try to work for Me. Because by working for Me you will come to the perfect stage.
verses.transliteration: abhyāse 'py asamartho 'si mat-karma-paramo bhava mad-artham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi
verses.meaning: Krishna advises that if Arjuna cannot follow the principles of Bhakti-yoga, he should work for Him, which will lead to perfection.

verses.sanskrit: अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः। सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान्॥
verses.translation: If, however, you are unable to work in this manner, then take shelter of Me, giving up all the results of action and try to be self-situated.
verses.transliteration: athaitad apy aśakto 'si kartuṁ mad-yogam āśritaḥ sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān
verses.meaning: Krishna advises that if Arjuna is unable to work for Him, he should surrender the results of his actions and strive for self-realization.

verses.sanskrit: श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते। ध्यानात्कर्मफलत्यागस्त्यागाच्छान्तिरनन्तरम्॥
verses.translation: If you cannot take up this practice, then engage yourself in the cultivation of knowledge. Better than knowledge, however, is meditation, and better than meditation is renunciation of the fruits of action, for by such renunciation one can attain peace of mind.
verses.transliteration: śreyo hi jñānam abhyāsāj jñānād dhyānaṁ viśiṣyate dhyānāt karma-phala-tyāgas tyāgāc chāntir anantaram
verses.meaning: Krishna explains the hierarchy: knowledge is better than practice, meditation is better than knowledge, and renunciation of the results of action is best, leading to peace.

verses.sanskrit: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च। निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी॥
verses.translation: One who is not envious but is a kind friend to all living beings, who does not think himself a proprietor and is free from false ego, who is equal in both happiness and distress, who is tolerant,
verses.transliteration: adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of a devotee: non-envious, friendly, compassionate, free from possessiveness and false ego, equal in happiness and distress, and tolerant.

verses.sanskrit: सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः। मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मे भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
verses.translation: always satisfied, engaged in devotional service with determination and with his mind and intelligence fixed on Me—such a devotee is very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: santuṣṭaḥ satataṁ yogī yatātmā dṛḍha-niścayaḥ mayy arpita-mano-buddhir yo me bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna continues describing a devotee as always satisfied, self-controlled, determined, and with mind and intelligence fixed on Him, declaring such a devotee very dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः। हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
verses.translation: He by whom no one is put into difficulty and who is not disturbed by anyone, who is steady in happiness and distress, is very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate ca yaḥ harṣāmarṣa-bhayodvegair muktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a devotee as one who neither causes nor is disturbed by others, and who is steady in happiness and distress, declaring such a person very dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मे भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
verses.translation: One who is not dependent on the ordinary course of activities, who is pure, expert, free from cares, not affected by any story, and who has completely renounced all material endeavors is very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: anapekṣaḥ śucir dakṣa udāsīno gata-vyathaḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī yo me bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a devotee as independent, pure, expert, free from cares, impartial, and renounced of all material endeavors, stating that such a devotee is very dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति। शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः॥
verses.translation: One who neither rejoices nor grieves, who neither laments nor desires, and who has renounced both auspicious and inauspicious things—such a devotee is very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati śubhāśubha-parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a devotee as one who neither rejoices nor grieves, neither laments nor desires, and has renounced both good and bad, saying that such a devotee is dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः। शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः॥
verses.translation: One who is equal to friends and enemies, who is equipoised in honor and dishonor, heat and cold, happiness and distress, who is always free from contaminating association, who is always silent and satisfied with anything,
verses.transliteration: samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅga-vivarjitaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a devotee as being equal to both friends and enemies, equipoised in honor and dishonor, heat and cold, happiness and distress, and free from bad association.

verses.sanskrit: तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येन केनचित्। अनिकेतः स्थिरमतिर्भक्तिमान्मे प्रियो नरः॥
verses.translation: who is not dependent upon any residence, who is always engaged in devotional service, with his mind fixed on Me—that person is very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: tulya-nindā-stutiḥ maunī santuṣṭo yena-kenacit aniketaḥ sthira-matir bhaktimān me priyo naraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a devotee as accepting both blame and praise, silent, satisfied with anything, independent of residence, and with a mind fixed on Him, saying that such a person is very dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते। श्रद्दधाना मत्परमा भक्तास्तेऽतीव मे प्रियाः॥
verses.translation: Those who follow this imperishable path of devotional service and who completely engage themselves with faith, making Me the supreme goal, are very, very dear to Me.
verses.transliteration: ye tu dharmāmṛtam idaṁ yathoktaṁ paryupāsate śraddadhānā mat-paramā bhaktās te 'tīva me priyāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by stating that those who follow the path of devotional service with faith, making Him the supreme goal, are exceedingly dear to Him.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव क्षेत्रं क्षेत्रज्ञमेव च। एतद्वेदितुमिच्छामि ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं च केशव॥
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O my dear Kṛṣṇa, I wish to know about prakṛti [nature], puruṣa [the enjoyer], kṣetra [the field of activities], kṣetrajña [the knower of the field], knowledge, and the object of knowledge.
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva kṣetraṁ kṣetra-jñam eva ca etad veditum icchāmi jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ ca keśava
verses.meaning: Arjuna inquires about prakriti, purusha, kshetra, kshetrajna, knowledge, and the object of knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते। एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: This body, O son of Kuntī, is called the field of activities, and one who knows this body is called the knower of the field.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca idaṁ śarīraṁ kaunteya kṣetram ity abhidhīyate etad yo vetti taṁ prāhuḥ kṣetrajña iti tadvidaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna defines the body as the field of activities and the one who knows the body as the knower of the field.

verses.sanskrit: क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत। क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम॥
verses.translation: O scion of Bharata, you should understand that I am also the knower of the field of activities, and that I know every individual body. Knowledge of the body and the knower of the body is called knowledge.
verses.transliteration: kṣetrajñaṁ cāpi māṁ viddhi sarva-kṣetreṣu bhārata kṣetra-kṣetrajñayor jñānaṁ taj jñānaṁ mataṁ mama
verses.meaning: Krishna declares Himself to be the knower of all fields and states that true knowledge is understanding both the field and its knower.

verses.sanskrit: तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक् च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत्। स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्समासेन मे शृणु॥
verses.translation: Now please hear from Me a short description of this field of activity—how it is constituted, what its changes are, from where it is produced, who that knower of the field of activities is, and what his influences are.
verses.transliteration: tat kṣetraṁ yac ca yādṛk ca yad-vikāri yataś ca yat sa ca yo yat-prabhāvaś ca tat samāsena me śṛṇu
verses.meaning: Krishna outlines the topics to be discussed: the constitution, changes, origin of the field of activity, the knower of the field, and their influences.

verses.sanskrit: महभूतान्यहङ्कारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च। इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः॥
verses.translation: The five great elements, false ego, intelligence, the unmanifested, the ten senses, the mind, the five objects of the senses,
verses.transliteration: mahā-bhūtāny ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva ca indriyāṇi daśaikaṁ ca pañca cendriya-gocarāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the components of the field of activity, including the five great elements, false ego, intelligence, the unmanifested, the ten senses, the mind, and the five sense objects.

verses.sanskrit: इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं सङ्घातश्चेतना धृतिः। एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम्॥
verses.translation: desire, hatred, happiness, distress, the aggregate, the life symptoms, and convictions—all these are considered to be interactions of the field of activity.
verses.transliteration: icchā dveṣaḥ sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ saṁghātaś cetanā dhṛtiḥ etat kṣetraṁ samāsena sa-vikāram udāhṛtam
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes the field of activity as including desire, hatred, happiness, distress, the aggregate, life symptoms, and convictions.

verses.sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्। आचार्य्यमुपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः॥
verses.translation: Humility; freedom from pride; nonviolence; tolerance; simplicity; approaching a bona fide spiritual master; cleanliness; steadiness; self-control;
verses.transliteration: amānitvam adambhitvam ahiṁsā kṣāntir ārjavam ācāryopāsanaṁ śaucaṁ sthairyam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna begins to describe knowledge, starting with humility, freedom from pride, nonviolence, tolerance, simplicity, approaching a spiritual master, cleanliness, steadiness, and self-control.

verses.sanskrit: इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहङ्कार एव च। जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम्॥
verses.translation: detachment from sense objects; being free from false egoism; and perceiving the misery of birth, death, old age and disease—
verses.transliteration: indriyārtheṣu vairāgyam anahaṅkāra eva ca janma-mṛtyu-jarā-vyādhi-duḥkha-doṣānudarśanam
verses.meaning: Krishna continues describing knowledge as detachment from sense objects, freedom from false egoism, and perceiving the misery of birth, death, old age, and disease.

verses.sanskrit: असक्तिरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु। नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु॥
verses.translation: nonattachment to children, wife, home and the like; evenmindedness amid pleasant and unpleasant events; and constant devotion to Me, without deviation—
verses.transliteration: asaktir anabhiṣvaṅgaḥ putra-dāra-gṛhādiṣu nityaṁ ca sama-cittatvam iṣṭāniṣṭopapattiṣu
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes knowledge as nonattachment to family, equanimity in pleasant and unpleasant events, and constant, undeviating devotion.

verses.sanskrit: मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्तिरव्यभिचारिणी। विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि॥
verses.translation: living in a secluded place; detachment from the general mass of people;
verses.transliteration: mayi cānanya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicāriṇī vivikta-deśa-sevitvam aratir jana-saṁsadi
verses.meaning: More qualities of knowledge: exclusive devotion to Him, living in seclusion, and detachment from ordinary people.

verses.sanskrit: अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम्। एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा॥
verses.translation: and acceptance of the importance of self-realization, and philosophical search for the Absolute Truth—this I declare to be knowledge, and what is beyond this is ignorance.
verses.transliteration: adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvaṁ tattva-jñānārtha-darśanam etaj jñānam iti proktam ajñānaṁ yad ato 'nyathā
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes the description of knowledge with self-realization and the philosophical search for the Absolute Truth, defining ignorance as that which is contrary to these.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वामृतमश्नुते। अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते॥
verses.translation: I shall now explain the knowable, knowing which you will taste the eternal. The Brahman, the spirit, is beginningless, subordinate to Me, and lies beyond the cause and effect of this material world.
verses.transliteration: jñeyaṁ yat tat pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvāmṛtam aśnute anādi-mat paraṁ brahma na sat tan nāsad ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna introduces the knowable, the Brahman, as beginningless, subordinate to Him, and beyond material cause and effect, knowing which one attains the eternal.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वतःपाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम्। सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति॥
verses.translation: That Brahman has its hands, legs, eyes, heads, and faces everywhere. It has its ears everywhere. In that way it exists, encompassing everything.
verses.transliteration: sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādaṁ tat sarvato 'kṣi-śiro-mukham sarvataḥ śruti-mal loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the Brahman as having senses everywhere, encompassing and existing in everything.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम्। असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च॥
verses.translation: The Supersoul, although the original source of all senses, is without senses. Though unattached, He is the maintainer of all living beings. He transcends the modes of nature, and at the same time He is the master of all the modes of material nature.
verses.transliteration: sarvendriya-guṇābhāsaṁ sarvendriya-vivarjitam asaktaṁ sarva-bhṛc caiva nirguṇaṁ guṇa-bhoktṛ ca
verses.meaning: The Supersoul is described as the source of all senses, yet without them; unattached, yet the maintainer; beyond the modes of nature, yet the master of them.

verses.sanskrit: बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च। सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत्॥
verses.translation: It exists outside of all beings and is also within. It is unmoving, and yet it moves. It is far away, and yet it is very near. It is knowable only to the advanced in knowledge.
verses.transliteration: bahir antaś ca bhūtānām acaraṁ caram eva ca sūkṣmatvāt tad avijñeyaṁ dūra-sthaṁ cāntike ca tat
verses.meaning: The Supersoul exists within and outside all beings, is both moving and unmoving, far and near, and knowable only to the advanced.

verses.sanskrit: अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम्। भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च॥
verses.translation: Although undivided, the Supersoul appears to be divided among many. He exists as the maintainer of every living being, and He devours and develops all.
verses.transliteration: avibhaktaṁ ca bhūteṣu vibhaktam iva ca sthitam bhūta-bhartṛ ca taj jñeyaṁ grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca
verses.meaning: The Supersoul, though undivided, appears divided, maintains every being, and both devours and develops all.

verses.sanskrit: ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते। ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य धिष्ठितम्॥
verses.translation: He is the source of light in all luminous objects. He is beyond the darkness of matter and is unmanifested. He is knowledge, He is the object of knowledge, and He is the goal of knowledge. He is situated in everyone’s heart.
verses.transliteration: jyotiṣām api taj jyotis tamasaḥ param ucyate jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ jñāna-gamyaṁ hṛdi sarvasya dhiṣṭhitam
verses.meaning: The Supersoul is the source of light, beyond darkness, unmanifested, is knowledge, the object and goal of knowledge, and is situated in everyone's heart.

verses.sanskrit: इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः। मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते॥
verses.translation: Thus the field of activities [the body], knowledge, and the knowable have been described comprehensively. Only those who accept this can become My devotees. Thereafter they can attain Me.
verses.transliteration: iti kṣetraṁ tathā jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ coktaṁ samāsataḥ mad-bhakta etad vijñāya mad-bhāvāyopapadyate
verses.meaning: Krishna summarizes the description of the field, knowledge, and the knowable, stating that understanding this leads to devotion and ultimately to Him.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादी उभावपि। विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसम्भवान्॥
verses.translation: Material nature and the living entities should be understood to be beginningless. Their transformations and the modes of matter are products of material nature.
verses.transliteration: prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva viddhy anādī ubhāv api vikārāṁś ca guṇāṁś caiva viddhi prakṛti-sambhavān
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that both material nature and living entities are beginningless, and that transformations and modes of matter arise from material nature.

verses.sanskrit: पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान् गुणान्। कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु॥
verses.translation: The living entity in material nature thus follows the ways of life, enjoying the three modes of nature. Thus he meets with good and evil among the various species.
verses.transliteration: puruṣaḥ prakṛti-stho hi bhuṅkte prakṛti-jān guṇān kāraṇaṁ guṇa-saṅgo 'sya sad-asad-yoni-janmasu
verses.meaning: The living entity in material nature enjoys the three modes, leading to good and evil births in various species.

verses.sanskrit: उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः। परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन् पुरुषः परः॥
verses.translation: Yet there is another transcendental enjoyer, who is the Lord, the supreme proprietor, who exists as the overseer and permitter, and who is known as the Supersoul.
verses.transliteration: upadraṣṭānumantā ca bhartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ paramātmeti cāpy ukto dehe 'smin puruṣaḥ paraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna introduces the Supersoul as the transcendental enjoyer, the Lord, the supreme proprietor, overseer, and permitter.

verses.sanskrit: अनुमन्ता विशसिता प्रभुः। साक्षी उपद्रष्टा
verses.translation: (Missing translation)
verses.transliteration: (Missing transliteration)
verses.meaning: (Missing meaning)

verses.sanskrit: य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह। सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते॥
verses.translation: One who understands this philosophy concerning material nature, the living entity and the interaction of the modes of nature is sure to attain liberation. He will not take birth here again, regardless of his present position.
verses.transliteration: ya evaṁ vetti puruṣaṁ prakṛtiṁ ca guṇaiḥ saha sarvathā vartamāno 'pi na sa bhūyo 'bhijāyate
verses.meaning: Understanding the philosophy of material nature, the living entity, and their interactions leads to liberation and the end of rebirth.

verses.sanskrit: ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना। अन्ये साङ्ख्येन योगेन कर्मयोगेन चापरे॥
verses.translation: Some perceive the Supersoul within themselves through meditation, others through the cultivation of knowledge, and still others through working without fruitive desire.
verses.transliteration: dhyānenātmani paśyanti kecid ātmānam ātmanā anye sāṅkhyena yogena karma-yogena cāpare
verses.meaning: The Supersoul is perceived through meditation, knowledge, and selfless action.

verses.sanskrit: अन्ये त्वजानन्तः श्रुत्वाऽन्येभ्य उपासते। तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायाणाः॥
verses.translation: Again there are those who, although not conversant in spiritual knowledge, begin to worship the Supreme Lord upon hearing from others. Because of their tendency to hear from authorities, they also transcend the path of birth and death.
verses.transliteration: anye tv ajānantaḥ śrutvānyebhya upāsate te 'pi cātitaranty eva mṛtyuṁ śruti-parāyaṇāḥ
verses.meaning: Even those who lack spiritual knowledge but worship the Lord by hearing from authorities can transcend birth and death.

verses.sanskrit: यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम्। क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ॥
verses.translation: O best of the Bhāratas, know that whatever you see in existence, both the moving and the nonmoving, is only a combination of the field of activities and the knower of the field.
verses.transliteration: yāvat sañjāyate kiñcit sattvaṁ sthāvara-jaṅgamam kṣetra-kṣetrajña-saṁyogāt tad viddhi bharatarṣabha
verses.meaning: Krishna states that everything, moving and nonmoving, is a combination of the field of activities and the knower of the field.

verses.sanskrit: समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम्। विनश्यत्स्वविनश्यन्तं यः पश्यति स पश्यति॥
verses.translation: One who sees the Supersoul equally present everywhere, in every living being, does not degrade himself by a destructive mind. Thus he gradually reaches the supreme destination.
verses.transliteration: samaṁ sarveṣu bhūteṣu tiṣṭhantaṁ parameśvaram vinaśyatsv avinaśyantaṁ yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
verses.meaning: Seeing the Supersoul equally present in all beings leads to the supreme destination.

verses.sanskrit: समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम्। न हिनस्त्यात्मनात्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम्॥
verses.translation: One who sees that the Supersoul is present equally everywhere, in every living being, does not degrade himself by a destructive mind. Thus he gradually reaches the supreme destination.
verses.transliteration: samaṁ paśyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam īśvaram na hinasty ātmanātmānaṁ tato yāti parāṁ gatim
verses.meaning: Seeing the Supersoul equally in all beings prevents self-degradation and leads to the supreme destination.

verses.sanskrit: प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः। यः पश्यति तथात्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति॥
verses.translation: One who can see that all activities are performed by the body, which is made of material nature, and sees that the self does nothing, actually sees.
verses.transliteration: prakṛtyaiva ca karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśaḥ yaḥ paśyati tathātmānam akartāraṁ sa paśyati
verses.meaning: The one who sees that the body performs all actions and the self is inactive, truly sees.

verses.sanskrit: यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति। तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा॥
verses.translation: When a sensible man ceases to see different identities due to the material body and he sees how beings are bred on various plans, he attains to the Brahman conception.
verses.transliteration: yadā bhūta-pṛthag-bhāvam eka-stham anupaśyati tata eva ca vistāraṁ brahma sampadyate tadā
verses.meaning: Seeing the unified source of diverse beings leads to the Brahman conception.

verses.sanskrit: अनादित्वा निर्गुणत्वात् परमात्मायमव्ययः। शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते॥
verses.translation: Those with the vision of eternity can see that the imperishable soul is transcendental, eternal, and beyond the modes of nature. Despite contact with the material body, O Arjuna, the soul neither does anything nor is entangled.
verses.transliteration: anāditvān nirguṇatvāt paramātmāyam avyayaḥ śarīra-stho 'pi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate
verses.meaning: The eternal, transcendental soul, being beyond the modes of nature, is neither the doer nor entangled, even in contact with the material body.

verses.sanskrit: यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते। सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथात्मा नोपलिप्यते॥
verses.translation: The sky, due to its subtle nature, does not mix with anything, although it is all-pervading. Similarly, the soul, being situated in the body, does not mix with it.
verses.transliteration: yathā sarva-gataṁ saukṣmyād ākāśaṁ nopalipyate sarvatrāvasthito dehe tathātmā nopalipyate
verses.meaning: Just as the all-pervading sky remains unmixed, the soul, though in the body, remains unmixed.

verses.sanskrit: यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः। क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत॥
verses.translation: O Arjuna, as the sun alone illuminates all this universe, so does the soul alone illuminate the entire body.
verses.transliteration: yathā prakāśayaty ekaḥ kṛtsnaṁ lokam imaṁ raviḥ kṣetraṁ kṣetrī tathā kṛtsnaṁ prakāśayati bhārata
verses.meaning: As the sun illuminates the entire universe, the soul illuminates the entire body.

verses.sanskrit: य एवं परं वेत्ति सत्त्वं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह। सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते॥
verses.translation: One who sees this difference between the body and the knower of the body, and can also understand the process of liberation from this bondage, attains to the supreme goal.
verses.transliteration: ya evaṁ paraṁ vetti sattvaṁ prakṛtiṁ ca guṇaiḥ saha sarvathā vartamāno 'pi na sa bhūyo 'bhijāyate
verses.meaning: The verse emphasizes that understanding the distinction between the body, the knower of the body, and the process of liberation leads to the supreme goal, and such a person does not take birth again.

verses.sanskrit: क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा। भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम्॥
verses.translation: Those who perceive with the eyes of knowledge the difference between the body and the knower of the body, and the process of release from material nature, attain the supreme destination.
verses.transliteration: kṣetra-kṣetrajñayor evam antaraṁ jñāna-cakṣuṣā bhūta-prakṛti-mokṣaṁ ca ye vidur yānti te param
verses.meaning: The verse emphasizes that understanding the distinction between the body, the knower of the body, and the process of liberation leads to the supreme goal, and such a person does not take birth again.

chapters.chapter_name: The Three Modes of Material Nature

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्। यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Again I shall declare to you this supreme wisdom, the best of all knowledge, by knowing which all the sages attained the supreme perfection.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna begins by promising to reveal supreme wisdom, the best of all knowledge, which leads sages to perfection.

verses.sanskrit: इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः। सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च॥
verses.translation: Being fixed in this knowledge, they attain to My transcendental nature and are thus not subjected to birth and death at the time of creation and annihilation.
verses.transliteration: idaṁ jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ sarge 'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that by adhering to this knowledge, one attains His nature and transcends the cycles of birth and death.

verses.sanskrit: मम योनिर्महद् ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम्। सम्भवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत॥
verses.translation: The total material substance, called Brahman, is My source of birth, and it is that Brahman into which I impregnate the living entities, making possible the births of all beings.
verses.transliteration: mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham sambhavaḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna describes Brahman as the source of material existence, which He impregnates with living entities to enable their birth.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः। तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता॥
verses.translation: It should be understood that all species of life, O son of Kuntī, are made possible by birth in this material nature, and that I am the seed-giving father.
verses.transliteration: sarva-yoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ tāsāṁ brahma mahad yonir ahaṁ bīja-pradaḥ pitā
verses.meaning: Krishna clarifies that all species of life are born from material nature, and He is the father who provides the seed.

verses.sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः। निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनम्॥
verses.translation: Material nature consists of three modes—goodness, passion and ignorance. When the eternal living entity comes into contact with nature, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he becomes conditioned by these modes.
verses.transliteration: sattvaṁ rajas tama iti guṇāḥ prakṛti-sambhavāḥ nibadhnanti mahā-bāho dehe dehinam
verses.meaning: Krishna introduces the three modes of material nature—goodness, passion, and ignorance—and explains how they condition the living entity.

verses.sanskrit: तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्। सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ॥
verses.translation: O sinless one, the mode of goodness, being purer than the others, is illuminating, and it frees one from all sinful reactions. Those situated in that mode become conditioned by a sense of happiness and knowledge.
verses.transliteration: tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśakam anāmayam sukha-saṅgena badhnāti jñāna-saṅgena ca anagha
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the mode of goodness as pure, illuminating, and freeing from sin, but also conditioning one with a sense of happiness and knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्। तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्॥
verses.translation: The mode of passion is born of unlimited desires and longings, O son of Kuntī, and because of this the embodied living entity is bound by fruitive action.
verses.transliteration: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇā-saṅga-samudbhavam tan nibadhnāti kaunteya karma-saṅgena dehinam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the mode of passion as born of desire and attachment, binding the embodied being to fruitive action.

verses.sanskrit: तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्। प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत॥
verses.translation: O son of Bharata, know that the mode of ignorance, which bewilders all embodied living entities, is born of darkness. The results of this mode are madness, indolence and sleep, which bind the conditioned soul.
verses.transliteration: tamas tv ajñānajaṁ viddhi mohanaṁ sarva-dehinām pramādālasya-nidrābhis tan nibadhnāti bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the mode of ignorance as born of darkness, deluding all beings, and binding them with madness, indolence, and sleep.

verses.sanskrit: सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत। ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत॥
verses.translation: O son of Bharata, the mode of goodness conditions one to happiness; passion conditions one to fruitive action; and ignorance, covering one’s knowledge, conditions one to madness.
verses.transliteration: sattvaṁ sukhe sañjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata jñānam āvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde sañjayaty uta
verses.meaning: Krishna summarizes that goodness leads to happiness, passion to action, and ignorance, by covering knowledge, leads to madness.

verses.sanskrit: रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत। रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा॥
verses.translation: Sometimes the mode of goodness becomes prominent, defeating the modes of passion and ignorance, O son of Bharata. Sometimes the mode of passion becomes prominent, defeating goodness and ignorance. And at other times the mode of ignorance becomes prominent, defeating goodness and passion.
verses.transliteration: rajas tamaś cābhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaś caiva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā
verses.meaning: Krishna explains how the three modes compete for dominance, with goodness defeating passion and ignorance, and so on.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते। ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत॥
verses.translation: The manifestations of the mode of goodness can be experienced when one is illuminated by knowledge in every bodily activity.
verses.transliteration: sarva-dvāreṣu dehe 'smin prakāśa upajāyate jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyād vivṛddhaṁ sattvam ity uta
verses.meaning: Krishna describes that when knowledge illuminates every bodily activity, it indicates the prominence of the mode of goodness.

verses.sanskrit: लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा। रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ॥
verses.translation: O chief of the Bhāratas, when there is a great increase in the mode of passion, the symptoms of great attachment, fruitive activity, intense endeavor, and uncontrollable desire and hankering develop.
verses.transliteration: lobhaḥ pravṛttir ārambhaḥ karmaṇām aśamaḥ spṛhā rajasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that an increase in passion leads to attachment, fruitive activity, intense endeavor, and uncontrollable desires.

verses.sanskrit: अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च। तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन॥
verses.translation: When there is an increase in the mode of ignorance, O son of Kuru, darkness, inertia, madness and illusion are manifested.
verses.transliteration: aprakāśo 'pravṛttiś ca pramādo moha eva ca tamasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe kuru-nandana
verses.meaning: Krishna states that an increase in ignorance results in darkness, inertia, madness, and illusion.

verses.sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्। तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलां प्रतिपद्यते॥
verses.translation: When one dies in the mode of goodness, he is elevated to the pure, higher planets of those who know the higher truths.
verses.transliteration: yadā sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti deha-bhṛt tadottama-vidāṁ lokān amalān pratipadyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes that dying in goodness leads to elevation to the higher, pure planets of those who know the truth.

verses.sanskrit: रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते। तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते॥
verses.translation: When one dies in the mode of passion, he takes birth among those engaged in fruitive activities; and when one dies in the mode of ignorance, he is born in the animal kingdom.
verses.transliteration: rajasi pralayaṁ gatvā karma-saṅgiṣu jāyate tathā pralīnas tamasi mūḍha-yoniṣu jāyate
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that dying in passion leads to rebirth among the action-oriented, and dying in ignorance leads to birth in the animal kingdom.

verses.sanskrit: कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं फलम्। रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम्॥
verses.translation: The result of pious action is pure and is said to be in the mode of goodness. But action done in the mode of passion results in misery, and action performed in the mode of ignorance results in foolishness.
verses.transliteration: karmaṇaḥ sukṛtasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṁ phalam rajasaḥ phalaṁ duḥkham ajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
verses.meaning: Krishna details the consequences of actions under each mode: goodness leads to purity, passion to misery, and ignorance to foolishness.

verses.sanskrit: सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च। प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च॥
verses.translation: From the mode of goodness, real knowledge develops; from the mode of passion, greed develops; and from the mode of ignorance, foolishness, madness and illusion develop.
verses.transliteration: sattvāt sañjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva ca pramāda-mohau tamaso bhavato 'jñānam eva ca
verses.meaning: Krishna further explains that goodness leads to knowledge, passion to greed, and ignorance to foolishness, madness, and illusion.

verses.sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः। जघन्या गुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः॥
verses.translation: Those situated in the mode of goodness gradually go upward to the higher planets; those in the mode of passion live on the earthly plane; and those in the abominable mode of ignorance go down to the lower worlds.
verses.transliteration: ūrdhvaṁ gacchanti sattva-sthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ jaghanyā guṇa-vṛtti-sthā adho gacchanti tāmasāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the destinations attained under each mode: goodness leads upwards, passion keeps one in the middle, and ignorance leads downwards.

verses.sanskrit: नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति। गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति॥
verses.translation: When one properly sees that there is no other doer but these modes of nature, and one knows the Supreme Lord, who is transcendental to all these modes, he attains to My spiritual nature.
verses.transliteration: nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati guṇebhyaś ca paraṁ vetti mad-bhāvaṁ so 'dhigacchati
verses.meaning: Krishna says that realizing the modes of nature as the sole doers and knowing the Lord as transcendental to them leads to attaining His spiritual nature.

verses.sanskrit: गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान्। जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते॥
verses.translation: When the embodied being is able to transcend these three modes associated with the material body, he can become freed from birth, death, old age and their distresses and can enjoy nectar even in this life.
verses.transliteration: guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān janma-mṛtyu-jarā-duḥkhair vimukto 'mṛtam aśnute
verses.meaning: Krishna states that transcending the three modes frees one from birth, death, old age, and their miseries, enabling the enjoyment of nectar.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतामतीतो भवति प्रभो। किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते॥
verses.translation: Arjuna inquired: O my Lord, by what signs is one known who is transcendental to these three modes? What is his behavior? And how does he transcend the modes of nature?
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca kair liṅgais trīn guṇān etān atīto bhavati prabho kim ācāraḥ kathaṁ caitāṁs trīn guṇān ativartate
verses.meaning: Arjuna asks Krishna about the characteristics, behavior, and means of transcending the three modes.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव। न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: One who does not hate illumination, attachment and delusion when they are present or long for them when they disappear; who is unwavering and undisturbed through all these activities of the material modes; who remains neutral,...
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca prakāśaṁ ca pravṛttiṁ ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava na dveṣṭi samprāvṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati
verses.meaning: Krishna describes a transcendent person as one who does not hate the presence of illumination, attachment, or delusion, nor long for their absence, and remains unwavering.

verses.sanskrit: उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते। गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येवं योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्ग्यते॥
verses.translation: ...who is transcendental to the modes of nature, who is situated apart, as if neutral, and who knows that the modes are acting—who remains firm and is never shaken,
verses.transliteration: udāsīnavad āsīno guṇair yo na vicālyate guṇā vartanta ity evaṁ yo 'vatiṣṭhati neṅgyate
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes the transcendent person as neutral, unmoved by the modes, and aware that the modes are simply acting.

verses.sanskrit: समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः। तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः॥
verses.translation: who regards happiness and distress alike; who looks upon a lump of earth, a stone and a piece of gold with an equal eye; who is equal toward the desirable and the undesirable; who is steady, situated equally in praise and blame, honor and dishonor;
verses.transliteration: sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ sva-sthaḥ sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ tulya-priyāpriyo dhīras tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna continues, describing the transcendent person as equal in happiness and distress, and towards earth, stone, and gold; and equipoised in desirable and undesirable situations, praise and blame.

verses.sanskrit: मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते॥
verses.translation: who is equal to friends and enemies; who has given up all material activities—such a person is said to be transcendental to the modes of nature.
verses.transliteration: mānāpamānayos tulyas tulyo mitrāri-pakṣayoḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by describing the transcendent person as equal to friends and enemies and renouncing all material activities.

verses.sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते। स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान् ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥
verses.translation: One who engages in the unalloyed devotional service, who does not fall down in any circumstance, at once transcends the modes of material nature and thus comes to the level of Brahman.
verses.transliteration: māṁ ca yo 'vyabhicāreṇa bhakti-yogena sevate sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
verses.meaning: Krishna reveals that unalloyed devotional service enables one to transcend the modes of nature and attain the level of Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च। शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च॥
verses.translation: And I am the basis of the impersonal Brahman, which is immortal, imperishable and eternal and is the constitutional position of ultimate happiness.
verses.transliteration: brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham amṛtasyāvyayasya ca śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by declaring Himself as the basis of the impersonal Brahman, the source of immortality, eternality, ultimate dharma, and unending happiness.

chapters.chapter_name: The Yoga of the Supreme Person

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम्। छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित्॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: There is a banyan tree which has its roots upward and its branches down and whose leaves are the Vedic hymns. One who knows this tree is the knower of the Vedas.
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śākham aśvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam chandāṁsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa veda-vit
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the metaphorical banyan tree with roots upward and branches downward, whose leaves are the Vedic hymns. Knowing this tree signifies Vedic knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा गुणप्रवृद्ध विषयप्रवालाः। अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके॥
verses.translation: The branches of this tree extend downward and upward, nourished by the modes of material nature. The twigs are the objects of the senses. This tree also has roots going down, which are bound to the fruitive actions of human society.
verses.transliteration: adhaś cordhvaṁ prasṛtās tasya śākhā guṇa-pravṛddhā viṣaya-pravālāḥ adhaś ca mūlāny anusantatāni karmānubandhīni manuṣya-loke
verses.meaning: Krishna elaborates on the tree's branches extending in both directions, nourished by the modes of nature, with sense objects as twigs and roots extending downwards, tied to human actions.

verses.sanskrit: न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते नान्तो न चादिर्न च सम्प्रतिष्ठा। अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलमसङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा॥
verses.translation: The real form of this tree cannot be perceived in this world. No one can know where it begins, where it ends, or where its foundation is. This banyan tree, with its roots growing strongly, must be cut down with the weapon of detachment.
verses.transliteration: na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādir na ca sampratiṣṭhā aśvattham enaṁ su-virūḍha-mūlam asanga-śastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā
verses.meaning: Krishna states that the tree's true form is imperceptible, with no clear beginning, end, or foundation. It must be severed with the strong weapon of detachment.

verses.sanskrit: ततः पदं तत् परिमार्गितव्यं यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः। तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी॥
verses.translation: Thereafter, one must seek that place from which, having gone, one never returns, and there surrender to that Supreme Personality of Godhead from whom everything began long ago.
verses.transliteration: tataḥ padaṁ tat parimārgitavyaṁ yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ tam eva cādyaṁ puruṣaṁ prapadye yataḥ pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī
verses.meaning: Krishna advises seeking the place of no return and surrendering to the Supreme Person, the origin of everything.

verses.sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः। द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसञ्ज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढः पदमव्ययं तत्॥
verses.translation: Those who are free from false prestige, illusion, and false association, who understand the eternal, who are done with material lust, who are freed from the dualities of happiness and distress, and who know how to surrender unto the Supreme Person attain to that eternal kingdom.
verses.transliteration: nirmana-mohā jita-saṅga-doṣā adhyātma-nityā vinivṛtta-kāmāḥ dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukha-duḥkha-saṁjñair gacchanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṁ tat
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of those who attain the eternal kingdom: freedom from false pride, illusion, and attachment, understanding the eternal, being free from lust and dualities, and surrendering to the Supreme Person.

verses.sanskrit: न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः। यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम॥
verses.translation: That supreme abode of Mine is not illumined by the sun or moon, nor by fire or electricity. Those who reach it never return to this material world.
verses.transliteration: na tad bhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
verses.meaning: Krishna describes His supreme abode as self-illuminating, not dependent on external sources like the sun, moon, or fire, and the destination from which one never returns.

verses.sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः। मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति॥
verses.translation: The living entities in this conditioned world are My eternal fragmental parts. Due to conditioned life, they are struggling very hard with the six senses, which include the mind.
verses.transliteration: mamai vāṁśo jīva-loke jīva-bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ manaḥ-ṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛti-sthāni karṣati
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that living entities in the material world are His eternal parts, struggling with the six senses, including the mind, due to their conditioned state.

verses.sanskrit: शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः। गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात्॥
verses.translation: The living entity in the material world carries his different conceptions of life from one body to another, as the air carries aromas.
verses.transliteration: śarīraṁ yad avāpnoti yac cāpy utkrāmatīśvaraḥ gṛhītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśayāt
verses.meaning: Krishna illustrates how the living entity carries its conceptions of life from one body to the next, similar to how air carries aromas.

verses.sanskrit: श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च। अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते॥
verses.translation: The living entity, thus taking another gross body, obtains a certain type of ear, eye, tongue, nose and skin, centered around the mind. And thus he enjoys a particular set of sense objects.
verses.transliteration: śrotraṁ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṁ ca rasanaṁ ghrāṇam eva ca adhiṣṭhāya manaś cāyaṁ viṣayān upasevate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes how the living entity, upon acquiring a new body, also gains corresponding senses centered around the mind to enjoy specific sense objects.

verses.sanskrit: उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम्। विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः॥
verses.translation: The foolish cannot understand how a living entity can quit his body, nor can they understand what sort of body he is under the spell of material nature. But one whose eyes are trained in knowledge can see all this.
verses.transliteration: utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vāpi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam vimūḍhā nānupaśyanti paśyanti jñāna-cakṣuṣaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna contrasts the perception of the foolish, who cannot comprehend the transmigration of the soul, with that of those with knowledge, who can see it clearly.

verses.sanskrit: यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम्। यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः॥
verses.translation: The endeavoring transcendentalists, who are self-situated, can see the self clearly. But those whose minds are not developed and who are not self-situated cannot see what is happening.
verses.transliteration: yatanto yoginaś cainaṁ paśyanty ātmany avasthitam yatanto 'py akṛtātmāno nainaṁ paśyanty acetasaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that self-realized transcendentalists can perceive the self, while those with undeveloped minds cannot.

verses.sanskrit: यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम्। यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम्॥
verses.translation: The splendor of the sun, which dissipates the darkness of this whole world, comes from Me. And the splendor of the moon and that of fire are also from Me.
verses.transliteration: yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate 'khilam yac candramasi yac cāgnau tat tejo viddhi māmakam
verses.meaning: Krishna declares that the light and splendor of the sun, moon, and fire originate from Him.

verses.sanskrit: गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा। पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः॥
verses.translation: I enter into each planet, and by My energy they stay in orbit. I become the moon and thereby supply the juice of life to all vegetables.
verses.transliteration: gām āviśya ca bhūtāni dhārayāmy aham ojasā puṣṇāmi cauṣadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna reveals that He sustains the planets by His energy and nourishes vegetation by becoming the moon.

verses.sanskrit: अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः। प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम्॥
verses.translation: I am the fire of digestion in the bodies of all living entities, and I merge with the incoming and outgoing breaths, digesting the four kinds of foodstuff.
verses.transliteration: ahaṁ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśritaḥ prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pacāmy annaṁ catur-vidham
verses.meaning: Krishna explains that He is the digestive fire in living beings, aiding in the digestion of the four types of food.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च। वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम्॥
verses.translation: I am seated in everyone’s heart, and from Me come remembrance, knowledge and forgetfulness. By all the Vedas, I am to be known. Indeed, I am the compiler of Vedānta, and I am the knower of the Vedas.
verses.transliteration: sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyo vedānta-kṛd veda-vid eva cāham
verses.meaning: Krishna declares that He is in everyone's heart, the source of memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. He is the object of the Vedas, the compiler of Vedanta, and the knower of the Vedas.

verses.sanskrit: द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च। क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते॥
verses.translation: There are two classes of beings, the fallible and the infallible. In the material world every living entity is fallible, and in the spiritual world every living entity is called infallible.
verses.transliteration: dvāv imau puruṣau loke kṣaraś cākṣara eva ca kṣaraḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭa-stho 'kṣara ucyate
verses.meaning: Krishna speaks of two types of beings: the fallible in the material world and the infallible in the spiritual world.

verses.sanskrit: उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः। यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः॥
verses.translation: Besides these two, there is the greatest living person, the Supreme Soul, the imperishable Lord Himself, who has entered the three worlds and is maintaining them.
verses.transliteration: uttamaḥ puruṣas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛtaḥ yo loka-trayam āviśya bibharty avyaya īśvaraḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna introduces the Supreme Soul, the imperishable Lord, who pervades and sustains the three worlds.

verses.sanskrit: यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः। अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः॥
verses.translation: Because I am transcendental to both the fallible and the infallible, I am known in the world and in the Vedas as the Supreme Divine Person.
verses.transliteration: yasmāt kṣaram atīto 'ham akṣarād api cottamaḥ ato 'smi loke vede ca prathitaḥ puruṣottamaḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna declares Himself as the Supreme Divine Person, beyond both the fallible and infallible, and thus known in the Vedas and the world.

verses.sanskrit: यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम्। स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत॥
verses.translation: Whoever knows Me as the Supreme Personality of Godhead, without doubting, is the knower of everything. He therefore engages himself in full devotional service to Me, O son of Bharata.
verses.transliteration: yo mām evam asammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam sa sarva-vid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna states that one who knows Him as the Supreme Personality of Godhead, free from doubt, is the knower of all and engages in full devotion to Him.

verses.sanskrit: इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ। एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत॥
verses.translation: This is the most confidential part of the Vedic scriptures, O sinless one, and it is disclosed now by Me. Whoever understands this attains the perfection of knowledge and thereby performs all that remains to be done.
verses.transliteration: iti guhyatamaṁ śāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛta-kṛtyaś ca bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes by saying that this most confidential knowledge from the Vedic scriptures, when understood, leads to perfection and the fulfillment of all duties.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः। दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्॥
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord said: Fearlessness, purification of one's existence, cultivation of spiritual knowledge, charity, self-control, performance of sacrifice, study of the Vedas, austerity and simplicity;
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca abhayaṁ sattva-saṁśuddhir jñāna-yoga-vyavasthitiḥ dānaṁ damaś ca yajñaś ca svādhyāyas tapa ārjavam
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the beginning of divine qualities: fearlessness, purity, spiritual knowledge, charity, self-control, sacrifice, study of Vedas, austerity, and simplicity.

verses.sanskrit: अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्। दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम्॥
verses.translation: nonviolence; truthfulness; freedom from anger; renunciation; tranquility; aversion to faultfinding; compassion for all living entities; freedom from covetousness; gentleness, modesty and steady determination;
verses.transliteration: ahiṁsā satyam akrodhas tyāgaḥ śāntir apaiśunam dayā bhūteṣv aloluptvaṁ mārdavaṁ hrīr acāpalam
verses.meaning: Krishna continues listing divine qualities: nonviolence, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, tranquility, aversion to faultfinding, compassion, freedom from greed, gentleness, modesty, and determination.

verses.sanskrit: तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता। भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत॥
verses.translation: vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, cleanliness, freedom from envy and the passion for honor—these transcendental qualities, O son of Bharata, belong to godly men endowed with divine nature.
verses.transliteration: tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucam adroho nātimānitā bhavanti sampadaṁ daivīm abhijātasya bhārata
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes the description of divine qualities: vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, cleanliness, non-enviousness, and humility, which belong to those with a divine nature.

verses.sanskrit: दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च। अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदमासुरीम्॥
verses.translation: Pride, arrogance, conceit, anger, harshness and ignorance—these qualities belong to those of demonic nature, O son of Pṛthā.
verses.transliteration: dambho darpo 'bhimānaś ca krodhaḥ pāruṣyam eva ca ajñānaṁ cābhijātasya pārtha sampadam āsurīm
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the qualities of those with a demonic nature: pride, arrogance, conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance.

verses.sanskrit: दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धाय आसुरी मता। मा शुचः सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव॥
verses.translation: The transcendental qualities are conducive to liberation, while the demonic qualities make for bondage. Do not worry, O son of Pāṇḍu, for you are born with the divine qualities.
verses.transliteration: daivī sampad vimokṣāya nibandhāyāsurī matā mā śucaḥ sampadaṁ daivīm abhijāto 'si pāṇḍava
verses.meaning: Krishna distinguishes between divine qualities, which lead to liberation, and demonic qualities, which lead to bondage, and reassures Arjuna of his divine nature.

verses.sanskrit: द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च। दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे शृणु॥
verses.translation: O son of Pṛthā, in this world there are two kinds of created beings. One is called the divine and the other the demonic. I have already explained the divine qualities. Now hear from Me about the demonic.
verses.transliteration: dvau bhūta-sargau loke 'smin daiva āsura eva ca daivo vistaraśaḥ prokta āsuraṁ pārtha me śṛṇu
verses.meaning: Krishna speaks of the two types of beings in the world—divine and demonic—and having described the divine, He now details the demonic.

verses.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुर् आसुराः। न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते॥
verses.translation: Those who are demonic do not know what is to be done and what is not. Neither cleanliness nor proper conduct nor truth is found in them.
verses.transliteration: pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca janā na vidur āsurāḥ na śaucaṁ nāpi cācāro na satyaṁ teṣu vidyate
verses.meaning: Krishna describes demonic people as lacking discrimination between right and wrong, and being devoid of cleanliness, proper conduct, and truthfulness.

verses.sanskrit: असत्यमप्रतिष्ठं ते जगदाहुरनीश्वरम्। अपरस्परसम्भूतं किमन्यत्कामहैतुकम्॥
verses.translation: They say that this world is unreal, without any foundation, and that there is no God in control. They say that it is produced of sex desire and has no cause other than lust.
verses.transliteration: asatyam apratiṣṭhaṁ te jagad āhur anīśvaram aparaspara-sambhūtaṁ kim anyat kāma-haitukam
verses.meaning: Krishna conveys the demonic view of the world as unreal, without foundation or divine control, and driven solely by lust.

verses.sanskrit: एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः। प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः॥
verses.translation: Following such conclusions, the demonic, who are lost to themselves and who have no intelligence, engage in unbeneficial, horrible works meant to destroy the world.
verses.transliteration: etāṁ dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya naṣṭātmāno 'lpa-buddhayaḥ prabhavanty ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣayāya jagato 'hitāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna says that the demonic, adhering to these views, engage in destructive and harmful actions that lead to the world's ruin.

verses.sanskrit: काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः। मोहाद्गृहीत्वासद्ग्राहान्प्रवर्तन्तेऽशुचिव्रताः॥
verses.translation: The demonic, who are insatiable in their lust, pride and deception, are so carried away that they are always engaged in unclean occupations, being attracted by that which is fleeting.
verses.transliteration: kāmam āśritya duṣpūraṁ dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ mohād ghṛhītvāsad-grāhān pravartante 'śuci-vratāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes the demonic as driven by insatiable lust, pride, and delusion, leading them to engage in impure activities and pursue impermanent things.

verses.sanskrit: चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः। कामोपभोगपरमाः एतावदिति निश्चिताः॥
verses.translation: They believe that to gratify the senses unto the end of life is the prime necessity of human civilization. Thus there is no end to their anxiety.
verses.transliteration: cintām aparimeyāṁ ca pralayāntām upāśritāḥ kāmopabhoga-paramāḥ etāvad iti niścitāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna notes that the demonic consider sense gratification the ultimate goal, leading to endless anxiety.

verses.sanskrit: आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः। ईहन्ते कामभोगार्थमन्यायेनार्थसञ्चयान्॥
verses.translation: Bound by hundreds of desires and tied by the bonds of lust and anger, they secure their own position by illegal means for the sake of sense gratification.
verses.transliteration: āśā-pāśa-śatair baddhāḥ kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ īhante kāma-bhogārtham anyāyenārtha-sañcayān
verses.meaning: Krishna adds that the demonic, bound by desires and driven by lust and anger, accumulate wealth unjustly for their gratification.

verses.sanskrit: इदमद्य मया प्राप्तमिदं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम्। इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यतीति॥
verses.translation: The demonic person thinks: “So much wealth do I have today, and I will get more wealth. So much is mine now, and it will increase in the future, more and more.
verses.transliteration: idam adya mayā prāptam idaṁ prāpsye manoratham idam astīdam api me bhaviṣyatīti
verses.meaning: Krishna reveals the thoughts of a demonic person, who is always focused on increasing their wealth and possessions.

verses.sanskrit: असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि। ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी॥
verses.translation: “He is my enemy, and I have killed him; and I will kill my other enemies also. I am the lord of everything. I am the enjoyer. I am perfect, powerful and happy.
verses.transliteration: asau mayā hataḥ śatrur haniṣye cāparān api īśvaro 'ham ahaṁ bhogī siddho 'haṁ balavān sukhī
verses.meaning: Krishna further describes the demonic person's thoughts, including their sense of superiority, power, and happiness, and their intent to harm their enemies.

verses.sanskrit: आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया। यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः॥
verses.translation: “I am rich and respectable. Where is there anyone equal to me? I will perform sacrifices, I will give some charity, and thus I will rejoice.” In this way they are deluded by ignorance.
verses.transliteration: āḍhyo 'bhijanavān asmi ko 'nyo 'sti sadṛśo mayā yakṣye dāsyāmi modiṣya ity ajñāna-vimohitāḥ
verses.meaning: Krishna concludes the description of the demonic mindset, noting their delusion about their wealth, status, and religiosity.

verses.sanskrit: अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः। प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ॥
verses.translation: Thus perplexed by various anxieties and bound by a network of illusions, they are too much attached to sense indulgence and fall into the hellish life.
verses.transliteration: aneka-citta-vibhāntā moha-jāla-samāvṛtāḥ prasaktāḥ kāma-bhogeṣu patanti narake 'śucau
verses.meaning: Krishna describes the fate of the demonic, who, perplexed by anxieties and bound by illusion, fall into a hellish existence due to their attachment to sense pleasures.
